reviewText:
Before anything, know that this game will make you suffer. It is not as easy as Bethesda or Bioware RPGs. Every single enemy will block, dodge, parry, counter, flank and break your defense, even at beginning when you cannot do all these stuff. You start the game without any skill or weapon and die for the first Sea Vulture you find. Your best friends until the end will be F8 and F9. That said, allow me to make some points:

•	Excellent graphics and atmosphere.
•	Excellent music.
•	Good story.
•	Good NPCs and voice acting, with fun dialogue.
•	Excellent monster models.
•	Decent animation: I liked especially the running animation for the player character.
•	Level up system is very good and unusual, same way as in the Gothic series, if you want more one point in dexterity, for example, you must talk with a trainer and pay gold for it. Moreover, gold is very hard to earn at the beginning.
•	I also enjoyed the fact that almost every NPC you find is important. Just a few of them are “generic”.

Some advices for who is going play the game for the first time:
•	Get the shield near the first ruin you find.
•	Put at least one level in smith, because the one-handed sword you make is better than any other you find in Chapter 1.
•	If you level up Sword, you will be able to use ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥-swords and two-handed swords in one hand, with a shield in the other. This works with Axe skill too, and axes make more damage.
•	Max for Alchemy skill, because that will allow you to make potions that increase stats permanently.
•	Increase the stat of your choice with trainers until they do not offer the dialogue option for this anymore. I think 100 is the max you can level up in this way. Then you can use potions to boost a bit more and it will be easy reach 200 or above in the chosen stat.

About mage spells, I cannot say what to do since I have played like warrior. However, you will need to use spells in many places. If you want to be warrior too, then just get some scrolls and you will be all right.

Cons: I cannot remember anything bad about Risen. There are some bugs off course, but which is the game that has not? Some people think the end is unsatisfying. Perhaps they were waiting for some big cut scene, what is not there. If you wait for the credits, you will listen the hero speaking with Patty and will know what happens next. That final talk in my opinion makes room for a sequel.

Finally, IMO Risen is a 10/10 RPG. A very hard and very rewarding experience. Every second I spend in this game was a memorable one.

reviewText:
Risen is a throwback to the days when Gothic 1 and Gothic 2 were considered kings of RPGs. After Piranha Bytes failed with Gothic 3, and the franchise went to other developers, they cut back on ambition and delivered an experience much like Gothic 1.

This experience consists of being a funny bigmouth, that starts as a complete newcomer and nobody in a fairly isolated, but lively territory, full of political intrigues, other bigmouths and hordes of monsters that will help you advance in your career as the local tough guy. The game is very combat-centric, and quite tough, but also very rewarding - every new piece of gear or move is a big thing in Risen, and might spell doom for the monster that you weren't able to take on previously, and, thus, allow you to explore some more of the fairly beautiful world.
Other attractions include dealing with pirates, smoking (swamp)weed and searching unsuccessfully for a guy you're supposed to meet in a brothel. And lots more!

the biggest downside this game has (and the previous gothic games, too, really) is the radical difference between early-to-mid game and late-game. just be prepared that this game becomes more and more combat-centric the deeper you get.

totally recommended, though.

reviewText:
This game is AWESOME, even considering all it's bad points.
Give it a try, and good luck with the Ashbeasts.

+ Decent voice acting and all lines are voice acted.
+ Good, difficult and slightly strategical combat system. You have to examine enemy patterns before commiting to a full on attack. You have to time your attacks to smoothly chain your hits.
+ Two factions with their own stories and quests.
+ Many, many sidequests.
+ You can explore whatever you want at any time you want.

=If you explore a lot of the map before moving onto the main story, you will be overpowered. And I mean it, take your time with the game unless you want to 1-3 hit anything before even reaching the second chapter.

- Punishing to players that rush the main story.
- The animations for some actions look weird (For example, cooking on a campfire makes your foot break).
- Towards the end game, it feels as though bows and crossbows arent very useful anymore since you can't use them to lure enemies towards you, they all come to you at the same time the first one is hit.
- A lot of enemies are just renamed basic enemies, leading to the game having only about 10~15 different enemies.

Please ignore my playtime, i just bought it and i played it 5 or 6 times without steam.

Risen is really nice, i bought it together with risen 2, and I like the first risen waaaaay better. It's from 2009, yes, but it is still really good and better than a lots of other modern RPGs. The Graphics are still good, sure there are better grphics now, but remember; its 5 years old and the graphics are really detailed, every corner of Faranga(thats how the island is called)was handmade, no generated s h i t. The enemys are not leveling up, which I really like cause its totally unrealistic when a wolf grows stronger and stronger and had at the end 10 times more damage. In Risen, there come new enemys when you enter a new chapter, and at these places where you shouldn't go at the beginning are harder enemys, real blockades are only at places for quests where it's simply nessesary. The Quest are realistic, too, I don't know why some people dont like them, I like these Quests more than  Kill-this-this-and-this-Quest, and there a lot of killing in Risen too.
The combatsystem is reallly good too, dont know why some slimshady guys here find it annoying, its really diversified, there are five types of weapons; Axes, Swords(one and two-handed), Crossbows, Bows and Staffs. There are many different weapons of these categorys, mostly swords and axes.

reviewText:
This game had so much potential.  It's almost like a Skyrim/Morrowind light.  Far smaller, simpler quests, but a decent world.  The BIGGEST drawback is the combat system.  It is not for the casual player.  If you want to just relax and crush some mob faces, this is not for you.  This game is big on player timed dodges, parries, and blocks.  Nothing is automatic.  The enemy can also parry, dodge, and block depending on their gear loadout.  This means you have to know how each and every mob likes to attack and tailor a different strategy for each and every mob type in the game.  You also have to know what attacks mobs can use based on the gear and type.  You can't just charge in and swing, you have to block, parry, dodge, counter-parry, and charge attack.

The margin for error is very small, especially on the hardest difficulty.  On one skeleton lord, It took about 35 strikes for me to kill it, while he would kill me in 3 hits.  This was pretty early on in the game but still, VERY little margin for error.  Wolves you have to lure into a tight pass where they can't dodge attack you, which is instant and practically unblockable.  Pro tip- Every mob in this game likes to circle to their left, which is to your right.  Strafe to the right as well to cut them off (footwork and positioning actually matters in this game)and stay away from their weapon hand.  If they lateral strike (yes there are also different swings and angles of attack based on your movement) and you dodge left you will still get clipped.

All that said, difficult/strategic combat and all, the BIGGEST flaw is the stupid console based forced focus system.  Holy %$#@ is that annoying for a PC user.  I get 3 boars charging me, I pull my sword and it sticky focuses the middle one, I strafe and it goes around the target and into the swings of another boar because your actions are based around your target, not just on your personal character control.  Developers just don't get how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ forced focus sticky targeting is compared to what PC users are used to (since xbox has no mouseplay).

All in all I did enjoy playing this game but it can be fantastically furiously frustrating at times because of the combat.  Oh and the clipping in this game is terrible.  Save often, you WILL fall through the world a LOT.  If I had a swear jar next to my PC I could have bought a new PC.

reviewText:
Game features one of the most beautiful worlds (for its time) and one of the least well drawn women.

In my opinion this is second best Piranha Bytes game after “Gothic II” (though original “Gothic” is really great, too). What we have here is an open world (but if some places are closed in the beginning for story reasons, and others’ dwellers beat the crap out of you if you go there too early), fairly interesting story, three ways to develop your character by joining one of two factions, fencing system that gets more complicated and effective when you upgrade your skills. Levelling up here just like original “Gothic” games require a mentor, which is good, and not all the skills are available for all the factions. Besides combat skills there are crafting, magical and thievery skills. Story is divided into few chapters, and finishing one changes a world a bit, adding some secondary quests and new enemies.

Overall this role-playing game definitely worth a play.

reviewText:
Worth the money thats for sure, its a good RPG that doesn't hold your hand, the combat can take a while of getting used to but it's rewarding when you figure it out because it requires thought instead of button mashing which will get you your ♥♥♥ handed to if you do, you actually start off as a complete joke with nothing but a stick and you'll probably be like 10 hours into the game until you start getting good weapons/armour.

The main story is pretty meh but i find the side quest's to be the most interesting, they're nothing amazing but they're fun and quite varied.

The graphics are gorgeous, the same during a sunset is one of the best sunsets you'll ever see in a video game and when you're strolling through the forest it looks amazing and the atmosphere is even better.

Its a very relaxing and atmospheric RPG, alot of the quest's dont involve any combat at all so you can just sit back and play it with a beer in one hand too.

Its not the most amazing game and its no classic but if you want a cheap RPG to satisfy your RPG thirst then this should be an instabuy, if you don't like RPG's you'll hate this, if you love RPG's you'll love this.

reviewText: I don't know what it is about these Pirhana Bytes games that keeps me so entertained. The Gothic series culminated in two games reknowned for their broken-ness but I still have played them for hundreds of hours and managed to enjoy myself. Risen is basically what Gothic 3 should have been (albeit with a different setting and plot but there are many similarities). The combat system is monumentally better and you can actually cast a spell without dying. The voice acting is still pretty terrible but you can get the picture and it doesn't detract too much from the game. People have likened the games to a low quality Elder Scrolls but the only real similarities are the open world and ... swords. Obviously the Elder Scrolls is better on an order of magnitude that can't be described but if you're into open world medieval settings and a pretty unique universe I'd say give it a go. It's worth the price.

reviewText: Risen is one of the best games I've played as of late. The combat system, while simplistic as a whole, is very much unique in it's execution. The story is more complex than I imagined and the freedom of any action in the game having a consequence was horrifying and hilarious. The world is beatuiful, except for the ash beasts, they were not beautiful until I got a legendary weapon and made them a smear on the ground. It is a very linear story at the heart of it, but the different factions are interesting and diverse enough that I would honestly play the game just to experience each one.\n\nIt was a gamble buying this game that I 100% do not regret. I highly reccomend it to anyone who favors anything I listed above.

reviewText:
I enjoyed this game a lot. The background lore is just ok but the game world itself is very alive. It is a small to medium open world but it is dense and all of the npcs feel like real characters in a story. There is no filler or wasted space.

Combat in Risen is relatively challenging, but IMO some people hype the difficulty too much... don't let that turn you off if you're not a super hardcore gamer or whatever. On the normal setting it really isn't that hard; it is just tough enough to require some strategy and timing, and to make it feel well-earned when you eventually become very powerful later on.

The game has an immersive atmosphere. It's not always super polished but the graphics are definitely nice (very different than the xbox 360 version) and the way it handles the world's lush vegetation is especially impressive. I have an older laptop and this game ran well- it seems to have the best graphics/performance ratio of any I've played on here.

reviewText:
A positive surprise. I've had this game forever and got it from some bundle. I decided to give it a try and I've never felt so bad for not trying a game earlier. The game has loads of your basic RPG elements, but there's some very unique ones too.

Interaction.
First thing that I noticed was how the interaction and fighting is implemented. You use middle mouse button to either draw or sheathe your weapon. While your weapon is drawn, you're in battle mode where you can't interact with anything other than hit stuff with your weapon. While your weapon is away, you can loot, talk and interact with items.
It's a great way to prevent you from accidentally hitting people while still making it possible to easily start slaughtering everyone, if you so wish.

Combat.
It's hard. Closest comparison in my mind would be Dark Souls. The enemies dodge, parry and use multiple different combinations to attact you, they deal loads of damage and are a serious pain in the ♥♥♥ if there are more than 1. You'll soon learn to quick save after every succesful battle / anything actually, since even after learning to fight against a single enemy they might just destroy you anyway with a long combo and powerful attacks.

Leveling up.
Instead of just gaining levels and being able to choose attributes to increase on a stat screen, you gain points that can be used to have a trainer teach you skills. I don't know if I skipped some hints, but I definitely didn't know this for a while. I ended up playing 3-4 hours without improving my skills. I don't need to tell you that it was pretty hard. Trainers can teach you to increase your strenght and weapons skills, as well as learn how to prospect or gut animals.

Quests.
Standard RPG quests. You talk to people, run to someone else, kill stuff, help people, etc. Nothing too new, but some freedom to do things. For example you can kill a lot of creatures early and start the quest later and finish it right away with the creatures being dead.

Bugs
The most noticeable bugs I had was the one related to Vsync. I basically couldn't jump up on ledges as I would get stuck, and I couldn't die from falling. The next one I noticed was that you're allowed to enter chapter 3 area before actually taking the quest for it. This caused me to not be able to progress and having to lose 2 hours of gameplay.


The game looks slightly old, but not bad. It's loads of fun to play and I'd recommend it to anyone.

My favourite thing? There doesn't seem to be any kind of inventory limit.

reviewText:
This is one of those game that deserve a neutral rating if Steam has one. Risen is an open world RPG, you are stranded on a island and has to join force with local factions and help them with their agendas to survive. I've only played a few hours at this point but the story is bland and uninteresting, VO can be all over the place. Most of the time it's not good.
Graphically RIsen can be a mixed bag. Flora looks good, environment is ok for a 2009 game but NPC looks bad. Design is bland and the town is pretty ugly.
As for the game play, Risen is play in third person view and structurally similar to other open world RPG, you wander around, explore and getting tons of quests. If you've played an open world RPG before like fallout, elder scroll  or the gothic series; you already know the general flow of the game.
The combat in this game is quite clunky, you can equip 2 weapon, one melee/staff, one range weapon. You don't have a lot of option for melee combat, just an attack and block button, range weapon is very slow but enemies are very easy to kite.
The leveling system is obtuse, you gained learning points after a level but can't spend them unless you go see a trainer and pay them gold to get stats increase. This lead to hilarious situation where you're in a school supposedly learning things but can't get any stats increase because there's no easy way to make money. This make the early game quite difficult since quest payout is 20/30 gold while you need increasingly more money to gain stats. 1 stat point cost 10-20 gold and you earned 10 stat points per level. Basically you will have to try and scavenge everything.
Depends on how you play the game though. the problem above can be completely trivial. You can get 1 point in sneaking and pickpocketing and proceed to steal everything from everyone. I became filthy rich just 30 mins after getting the skills and this broke the economy. Stealing is really easy in this game and require no trick, just engage in a conversation option and steal. I stole a soldier's shield as I was talking to him once, it's pretty funny.
Quest design is my biggest complain about this game, in open world rpg a good developer would give you multiple options to finish a quest. Not really the case in risen. people in this game are very easily agro if you are in a room and open a chest you're not supposed to. I accidentally agro an NPC and proceed to woop his ♥♥♥ and he refused to talk to me afterward thus making it impossible for me to finish a quest that involving him (you can get a spell to make them forget but in the early game I have I've only found 1 scroll so far). In another instant, I was supposed to get training from some dude, he made me fight him as a test, I won but click 1 time too much and he's dead, another impossible to finish quest. Worst of all these quest chains are necessary for you to get out of the monastery and I was stuck with no option to go out. Luckily I found a place to hop the fence and book it.

Despite all the ♥♥♥♥♥ing I've done, Risen still compelled me enough to play for more than 2 hour at a time and write a review for it. This is more than I can say for the CODs and ♥♥♥ creed out there. As clunky as it is, wandering around and ♥♥♥♥ing with the local NPCs is fun.

However, when you look at it objectively, RIsen is not a good game, there are good ideas in it but it's too clunkly and in some cases poorly implement. There are much better open world RPG out there, the Gothic series, its predecessor is one example. I can only recommend this game if you are a big fan of open world RPG and has exhausted all of your other options. Overall a 6/10 for me and recommendation with serious reservations.

Great game. I would highly recommend it if you like RPG's. It is the spiritual successor to the Gothic series, and it is quite similar in many ways. You can side with either the Bandits, or the Inquisition/Mages. I side with the Inquisition/mages almost every game I play, because being a Mage is just how I roll in almost all RPG's. The Bandits are scum anyway. If you want to be a Mage, make sure to sneak around the back end of Harbour town and complete every quest there in favour of the Inquisition. You will get a letter of recommendation from the leader of town there and if you helped a Mage representative in town, you can become a true Mage at the monastery using this letter of recommendation. If you dont do this, you will be forced to become a Warrior of the Order, a Warrior Mage hybrid class who cannot use rune spells like a Mage, only basic magic attacks.

Man this game was a blast. I had no idea what to expect going into it and after the initial lukewarm first impressions of the intro section I was hooked. The game strikes a very good spot in terms of difficulty where you need to put at least some thought into what stats you're upgrading and the equipment you use, but it never gets too hard or unfair. Even when you've gotten some baller new armour and weapons you never really feel safe against any enemy and fights stay fresh even if they technically are quite repetitive. The combat system itself is slightly clumsy but pretty fun overall, putting big emphasis on dodging or blocking correctly.

The world is very friendly towards exploring (being able to climb is awesome) and it rarely feels empty. Just when you get tired of walking long distances the game conveniently introduces its fast travel system. The game never throws that much info at you leaving you to find out what needs to be done yourself which is great. NPCs very often have new things to say and especially in the first half of the game you have a lot of freedom in how you want to complete your objectives. Discovering the game's intricacies never felt like a chore.

On the technical side I was a little annoyed by not being able to customise my mouse sensitivity or turn of acceleration. I also had physics bugs when climbing due to high fps, fixable of course but still annoying.

Graphically the game is dated and I very highly recommending increasing draw distance. Sadly NPCs and enemies have a very noticable hardcoded distance at which they will pop in, but most everything else you can tweak. Google it. I also installed sweetfx with a custom profile which made a big difference in terms of a sharper and more colourful look.

The story? Mostly forgettable, but does its job.

Highly recommend it, both for those that like RPGs and those that generally don't.

It's a nice game, regardless the bad x360 reviews. It's not a game for everyone, because it's rough around the edges, so people who are used to refined RPGs like the newer installments of The Elder Scrolls, might not like it.

Most of the places have a personality to them, but the game has some flaws.

Pros:
- interesting world
- reasonably nice visuals
- non-hack-n-slash combat

Cons:
- jumping/falling - is really bad and you can stick to the scenery sometimes
- the world could be bigger
- as you're nearing the end, the enemies get considerably stronger, so it can be a pain to get to the end
- i also found the last chapter boring/non-creative
- nothing is dynamically generated, so the game can feel too static. No enemy respawns, no random encounters, just some regenerating items (not all) in stores

So, it's definitely not for everybody, but it has it's strong points, so give it a try if you like older RPG titles.

Playing this game is like smashing your ♥♥♥♥ with a hammer repeatedly.

Perhaps one of the more underrated RPGs I've ever run across, Risen continues Pirahna Bytes' legacy of telling a familiar story in an exceptional way. Much like its Gothic predecessors, Risen puts the player in the shoes of an unnamed hero in an open world where resources and monsters do not periodically respawn and where the smallest mistake can punish you gravely.

The gameplay is simple but hard to master. It rewards those who grasp the need for timing and prediction as  Risen's enemies rarely signal their attacks and fighting large mobs of enemies is usually suicidal in part due the game's frustratingly flawed lock on system.  However, progression in combat skills offers flexibility in getting under an opponent's defenses rather than mere brute force, making combat somewhat easier, but requiring some level of brains to use it.

Risen isn't a typical hack and slash RPG, it is nothing like the Elder Scrolls series either. It is fairly punishing from the early and middle game but offers a sense of accomplishment through its finite resources and respawns and unique items only available in some of the most treacherous dungeons.

Graphically Risen isn't the most polished looking game in existence. Character models tend to look a little bland at times with tons of noticeable reuse popping up everywhere, but the tropical setting coupled with some of the mediterranean inspired architecture presents for a fairly interesting looking world once you get over the myriad of familiar faces. And unlike most open RPGS, Risen barely has any loading times outside of the initial start up--the world and all its dungeons are in one single zone rather than being divided into seperate ones--making for one of the most immersive RPGS I've ever played.

If you're a fan of old school RPGs, try out Risen as you might just like it.
35+ Hours of fun, recommended  to all Gothic fans!

reviewText: one of the most underrated RPG of all time

After the technical disasters of Gothic 3, Piranha Bytes have returned to form with Risen. Risen feels a lot similar to their original Gothic 1 masterpiece, but a bit more modern in many regards.

The world itself is much smaller [than Gothic 3], but much more interesting - especially in terms of questing & with what's going on in the world. Typical of PB's RPG's, the world is breathing & living - it is very immersive; NPC's run on a schedule; & the world has a high level of interactivity.

Also like most PB RPG's, the combat is still somewhat clunky & pales in comparison to other RPG's. Your decisions do matter in the actual story itself & will shape your Nameless Character and his skills. Some of the best stuff in the game is some of the side-quests, focusing on the theme of pirates.

While Gothic 1 is PB's true masterpiece, Risen is a close second or third for them & a major step in the right direction in many ways. If you like RPG's, you do owe it to yourself to play Risen.

Grade = B.
It's a very good RP-game, like a Gothic 3. 7,5/10
I RECOMMEND THIS

Risen is an amazing open world rpg with alot of free choices but a rather underwhelming ending.

After the first few minutes playing a short introduction you are free to roam the island as you wish, if you are new there will be some traps that can be more or less annoying depending on how you like to play (ie fighter or mage) but the world is quite large and nicely detailed with many places to discover.


Positive
Large area to explore
Alternative choices
Harvest plants and mine ores
Crafting (swords and trinkets)
Alchemy to create potions
Negative
Rather disappointing ending
Not much armor to find/buy
Neutral - everyone decides for himself whether this is good or bad :)
Beginner traps
Steep learning curve
Final resultsIf you like open world rpg's that give a challenge you should definetely give risen a chance, even if the ending may not be satisfying, considering the game time you can spend just exploring the island or doing side quests makes this game alot fun for me.

Risen is an amazing open world rpg with alot of free choices but a rather underwhelming ending.

After the first few minutes playing a short introduction you are free to roam the island as you wish, if you are new there will be some traps that can be more or less annoying depending on how you like to play (ie fighter or mage) but the world is quite large and nicely detailed with many places to discover.


Positive
Large area to explore
Alternative choices
Harvest plants and mine ores
Crafting (swords and trinkets)
Alchemy to create potions
Negative
Rather disappointing ending
Not much armor to find/buy
Neutral - everyone decides for himself whether this is good or bad :)
Beginner traps
Steep learning curve
Final resultsIf you like open world rpg's that give a challenge you should definetely give risen a chance, even if the ending may not be satisfying, considering the game time you can spend just exploring the island or doing side quests makes this game alot fun for me.

reviewText:
Fun game; but if you buy it, don't get it from steam. The game crashes if you play it on high graphics, and the only fix is a 4gb patch which steam doesn't allow.
There are also some bugs worth mentioning, like getting stuck in the air when jumping over some things, and getting stuck in the edge of cliffs when jumping around.
bugs can basically be fixed by not jumping in general- but where is the fun in that?

reviewText: A very simple Rpg but don't judge it too fast. It has great graphics for a 2009 game with some of the best lighting effects i ever seen in a video game. The exploration is probably the most strong aspect of the game, where you have an island to discover full of intricate paths, atmospheric dungeons, and fascinating creatures. In this aspect and others it may lack the presentation and ambition of the Elder Scrolls games but i felt more immersed in this one than in Skyrim. The way your character develops it's interesting as well, you start off very weak with some ragged clothes as armor and a stick as weapon and because of that you have to think if you want to engage someone in combat, but as you progress through the game and your hero becomes more stronger with better items (and believe me they are hard to get) you feel the sense of development, that your character has changed. The story is nothing of extraordinary as well the characters but it gets the job done.\nWhat can i say more about this game? Well a lot more really because it's one of those that there is more than meets the eye.\nPick it up, you can get it very cheap nowadays because Risen has been in several bundles.

reviewText:
So this game wasnt exactly what I expected it was somewhat different to the old Gothic matrix that I had assumed it would be. But in the whole it wasnt too bad. It wasnt quite as long as I expected but still quite fun.

Pros:
- Decent amount of side quests
- Decent story
- Really nice enviroment (Think this was the bit I enjoyed most about it)
- Storyline that matters (I.e your choices matter)

Cons:
- Multi fight combat is a nightmare at low level and at high level can still be quite challenging.
- The learning curve for combat at the beginning is way to high. I found some fights (In particular the Scordo fight) was a total nightmare at the beginning because you had no clue what you were doing still and the enemy can 2 shot you easy.
- There is no NPCs (Well besides Patty) which I felt like I could bond with, most of the NPCs felt like part actors rather then actual full actors unlike say Gothic (Xardas, Diego, Gorn, Lee etc etc)
- Doesnt feel like putting points in Crossbow/Bow actually does anything (I had 7 in crossbow and it still felt like I was firing at the same speed)

So overall i'd give it about a 65% good fun but still nothing compared to Gothic 2.

It's a shame that first two Gothic games are very old now, and it's a problem to properly mod it's graphics with an ENB for example.

reviewText:
Let's start with the fact, that this game reminds me a lot of the third Gothic. Probably because of the game mechanics and engine, but the feeling was nice. I really can't find any good games similar to the Gothic series. Fable was really cool, but the TES series in general is just not my cup of coffee.

I've tried Risen three times. Twice it bored me and I stopped after an hour or so, thinking I'll never get back to it. When I finally gave it a chance the third time, I finally got into it. So if you're not convinced at first, I suggest you just keep playing.

The game turned out to be really great. The plot is simple but epic, and the mere fact that you have to discover it first as a castaway who knows nothing and is nothing, was something that got me sticked to the screen for hours. So what does this game have that other don't?

The unique feeling of progress (just like Gothic). You get to see how powerful your character gets over time, slowly, but once you reach a certain point you know there's hardly anything that may stand in your way.
A living world that will feel like home after a while of playing.
Freedom to become a warrior, a hunter or a mage.
Two ways to follow the plot (as a warrior/hunter or a mage), both leading to the same ending but each with a different line of quests and each with a different backstory/reasons. Before you choose your path you hear from the people what they all think of one and the other. Then you get to choose and, similar to Gothic, you can base your decisions on which you think is good or evil.
Lizardmen! Temples!
Amazing music.
Bad sides?
No hunter game (I've spent hours hunting deer in G3)
No sprint (just walking is actually pretty fast but exploring may get a bit boring if you want to see every corner of the island)
I invested a lot in crossbows but even with the best crossbow in the game they were pretty useless.
Great potential, but feels a bit like it could be used a bit better. It's still a very good game, well made and seems to be a good opening game for a series. I am disappointed with the second game though but I guess I should just give it another chance, like with this one.
The second Risen game is generally different. I don't like it (yet?) because I prefer the first, but if you don't like the first you might like the other one. Either way both games are worth checking out, especially if you're a fan of the Gothic series.

reviewText: Absolutely rediculous combat mechanics. Frustrating to the point where I couldn't progress. Whenever you strike or dodge, you cannot move until that animation is complete, making strategic manouvering useless. When dodging an attack to strike back, they perform an animation to step back, meaning you miss and they leave you open for attack while you helplessly complete the animation. Enemies can stagger you at the slightest hit, yet you cannot stagger them; this makes the combat feel very unbalanced. I'm an experienced RPG player yet I think this combat system completely ruins the exploration of this game.

reviewText: An open world 3D RPG. The world isn't enormous, but isn't small either. The story isn't long, but isn't short either. The typical RPG stuff is here: quests, crafting, leveling up.\n\nSome of the best stuff is finding out how to beat hard situations by using some of the game's design against itself, like when I lured hard to kill monsters to an invincible NPC and made sure to get the last hit in so my character still received experience and loot. It adds another level of play that the developers probably hadn't intended.

reviewText:
The following will just be my opinions on various aspects of the game. Do with this as you please.

Combat: Slow and shallow BUT! Only at first glance. At a lower level in the game, you are pretty much the stereotypical ♥♥♥♥♥ swinging a blade with no actual angle of skill. Defeating enemies early on is purely out maneuvering your opponents and hitting them whilst their backs are turned or getting an opportunistic hit in between their shifts in defence.

As you progress and receive training, new tactics, such as parrying, become available and combat becomes remotely engaging and interesting. There's a sense of fulfillment when you've figured out the timing of your skill and the enemy's movements. (Ranged Combat and Magic are, well, Ranged Combat and Magic. Hit and run until dead.)

Progression: Leveling and character progression in this game is a bit strange. Where most RPGs would either give you free control over your Skill points or simply assign them for you, this game gives you points but demands that a player goes between trainers to progress. This in mind, side quests and optional dungeon crawling is much more rewarding, as it covers the fees of your trainers.

Dialogue: Personally, I feel that this is one of the weaker points of the game. Perhaps I've only messed with minor characters or maybe I'm just used to the more 'mainstream' RPG. Either way, the voice acting in this game is Drone-like and a bit bland.

General Atmosphere: Well, the game's music is decent, the graphics are 'OK' and the Map/Board/Whatever you prefer to call it, is pretty detailed. There are plenty of things to explore and find and I can't say that the map is bad to look at.

All-in-all, I'd toss this a 7/10.

reviewText:
События происходят в древнем и фентезийном мире. Главный герой плывёт на корабле, начинается шторм, корабль разбивается о рифы, а ГГ выкидывает на берег незнакомого острова. Как потом оказывается, остров окружили гигантские Титаны, которых призвал какой-то маг. Эти Титаны и вызывают шторма. А чтобы их успокоить ГГ придётся принять одну из двух сторон — бандиты или монахи, и найти доспехи титана. Это лишь кажется просто. На самом деле это всё очень и очень долго тянется по времени выполнения.

Плюсы игры: Схожесть с Готиками-1, 2, 3. Та же атмосфера, даже похожие имена у НПС, похожие монстры. Красивая графика. Отличное звуковое оформление. Интересный сюжет. Сложная, но интересная система поединков.

Минусы игры: Линейность. Концовка всего одна, кем бы вы не играли и как бы вы не играли. Маленький игровой мир. Мало квестов. Маловато оружия, а экипировки ещё меньше.

reviewText:
A great underrated rpg.
The gameplay is different from other RPGs such as The Elder Scrolls, Not everyone may like it.
The game can be really confusing sometimes, the quests, the map, pretty much everything but the game itself is really awesome, It's different from the other RPGs which is a plus.
Just 2 things I do not like which are the freeroam and the ending.
Do not except  The Elder Scrolls or even a Fallout game, it's open world but at the same time it's linear.
You cannot continue after the ending, not even a new game plus.

Those are 2 big flaws that are common in the games made by Piranha – Bytes.
For some, it could be positive but for a gamer like me, they are both flaws.
It's pretty much the same for every Gothic and Risen games, just that some have a better story, gameplay, items etc than the others.

If it was truly open world with unlimited freeroam and we would be able to continue playing after the end, I would probably give it a 9/10 but since it is not the case I'm giving it a 7.5/10


My favorite list:

1. Gothic II
2. Gothic
3. Risen
4. Gothic III
5. Risen 2: Dark Water
6. Arcania: Gothic 4 (I wouldn't consider this one as a Gothic game though)

They are all good In my opinion, but some are more worth than the others, of course, they all have their good and bad.
If only they would have a true freeroam and no ending.

7.5/10

reviewText:
It's a decent RPG in my opinion that follows the steps of it's predecessor, Gothic. And it does it pretty well. If you didn't get it on Humble Bundle, wait for a sale and play it right away. You won't be dissapointed!

Things that I like:
-good voice acting, a few cool and funny characters, as well as dialogues;
-the monsters and creatures respawn; (triggered by certain things like new chapter etc. )
-armor is very rare; it's expensive and you can only get it from joining factions. That makes you feel somewhat powerful and it's more rewarding this way;
-pickpocketing is fun; (you can even steal items in use :D)
-unlimited inventory, no carrying weight
-leveling up and spending learning points is highly rewarding and satisfying
-simplistic and cool UI

Things I don't like:
-the combat and it's animations are pretty clunky and it's kinda hard to excell at it
-lockpicking involves luck, not real 'skill'. Locks are not random and you can abuse this pretty easy with a quicksave. I'm not really complaining about this, but it could've been better.
-occasional bugs
-lacks of minimap. I used to have a compass on my screen but that dissapeared somehow.

Others:
-You can fast travel only when you get to chapter 2. There are 14 teleporting stones and you need to find them so you can be able to use them.
-you are going to spend most of your time walking, quicksaving, dying and quickloading

reviewText:
Risen is what I call a spiritual successor to the Gothic Series, more specifically Gothic 1 which the developers had previously lost the rights to before regaining them shortly after the release of Risen 2. Risen is by all rights an HD version of everything that was good about Gothic. The small map that seems daunting but becomes akin to the back of your hand after a few hours of exploration, tons of dense forestry with ruins to explore, and a relatively interesting story concept of humans banishing the gods and titans rising to take their place for dominance and destroy the humans.

Overall there is nothing that can be said is explicitly bad about Risen, there are some changes/complaints which I'll list but otherwise was nothing worth dismissing this game from being playable. I know there are plenty of people who complained about the 'old-fashionedness' which I can see nothing of in my playthrough.

If you liked any of Gothic, you'll simply fall in love with Risen, the atmosphere is great with everything that I had liked about Gothic. Sadly I felt that the humor was a tad off from the Gothic days were I found every quip to bring a half-smile to my face no matter how corny. In Risen many of the jokes/quips are short one liners that simply don't hit the same mark for some reason, and it's hard to pinpoint why that is.

Unlike Gothic 1, Risen decided to narrow the choices for the player with only including two different camps for the player to choose from with the Volcano Keep vs the Bandit Camp while Gothic had the Old Camp, New Camp, and the Swamp. It oftentimes feels as though Risen was originally going to have three divisions like Gothic but was changed to only have two instead, possibly because of compact the island was and how strange it would be to have three factions vying for control over the island. This was something I felt that Gothic had an issue with as the Old Camp was virtually non-existent until nearly the end of the game, which I think would have been the case if Harbortown was a seperate entity in Risen. My point is that in Gothic 1 both the Swamp and New Camp were interesting and everyone involved seemed to be pleasant which inticed you into a conflict of which faction to join. In Risen you have the Bandit Camp full of absolute dirtbags with the exception of the Smith and one or two other characters or the Volcano Keep where you get walloped until you join their faction unwillingly. Quite frankly I found myself hating both sides and often swindling whoever I could whenever possible.

Portal Stones were an addition to the game not unusual from the Gothic Franchise and while the original Gothic had only three stones; each for a differing capitol, Risen rose above to a grand total of 14 teleport stones. The only issue I have with the stones is that it spawns lizards that hold the stones in a wide variety of places that the player has quite likely already been, resulting in missing stones with no quest map to avail their needs. Furthermore these stones are often too close together and not far enough apart, some regions of the map have no teleport stone to have easy access to the area without running around or inside a mountain. This brings me into the map issue where while the map is densly packed with things to do there are certain regions that are used marginally once, and never set upon again. This is also addressed in my various complaints log where I state that the search is often left undone as the best stuff in the game is generally handed out to the player in plain sight with very few hidden goodies to treasure. The Berserker Sword for example is in one of the five endgame dungeons but can be accessed before even that chapter, as early as chapter 1 and is easily one of THE BEST WEAPONS in the game.
Now various complaints
-Traits or skill trees were worthless for the most part, sword/axe trees were only useful to equip 2h weapons with 1h, which means that attributes give far more weight
-Dexterity items were extremely lacking and it's disappointing that they put only ranged weapons in the grouping which were almost worthless
To me the sword skill should have grown off dexterity with dex having bows and swords - str having axes and crossbows - intel having staves and magic.
-Blacksmithing level 3 was absolutely worthless with many weapons easily outdoing any craftable weapon, only level 2 was worthwhile with Goldsmithing
-Acrobatics, Sneaking, Alchemy, Prospecting, and Gutting Animals were all absolutely mandatory and it seems weird that these were optional choices.
In that note Prospecting became worthless quickly after gaining the amount of gold you need and finding the jewelry you want. I collected well over 99 iron ore and obsidian ore with nothing of worth to create.
Alchemy allows you to create 'additional' permanent stat points but the game fails to explain that you can't level stats with learning points past 100 of any attribute which tricks players into using potions or stat increases before they hit the 100 mark when they could go up to 200 of any attribute. Additional stats in my opinion should have been a seperate variable that adds onto the characters base stats.
-When training skills if a ring is equipped that upgrades the skill you actually pay for the level ABOVE what skill you actually have.
-Odd game mechanics coming into play at the very end of the game forcing the player to press the same switch to open different doors which was never implemented earlier (literally in the last dungeon
-More about the final dungeon; there is an area that doesn't allow the player to use magics because the player could levitate over the gap and get stuck behind an immovable stone door. This was likely done to prevent players from getting stuck since it probably happened A LOT during the beta test of the game. It's extremely silly you can't use magic in only this location and made me fall to my death in areas located AROUND this location making me fall out of levitate for no reason until I got lower in the dungeon and found out why it was happening. Overall it was cheaply done to route the problem they were having instead of quickly designing a quick side path to let players escape, even a small hole could have supplemented with the transform snail spell.
-Often warped up to the top of different buildings when walking INTO the building
-Enemies would warp to a position around the player for some reason, especially annoying if you would get your enemy into a position to combo him easily to only have him warp around your character and combo you instead.
-Combat was rough, and the lockon system often felt off. Sadly this game doesn't do multiple enemy combat very well which there is A LOT of.
-Combat being Rough: Due to the jerkiness of the jump/dodge key which would terrorize combat with you being unalbe to jump back if a pebble or small incline was in your path.
-Sometimes attacks would just phase through enemies can't even explain this one
-Enemies jump back WAY TOO preemptively it gets really annoying and oftentimes you just have to force an enemy into a corner to stop them from jumping back
-No merchant talent which I thought would be insanely useful to increase sale prices, since you will only get 1/20 of the worth of any item you sell.
-Last boss was silly but I think most of the final bosses have always been silly for Piranha Bytes
-Quest Map was a seperate map instead of overlaying the Map UI when clicking on a quest, I have no idea why these two were made independently.
-Lack of 'dungeons' to explore, with final quest throwing 5 dungeons all at once that makes you hate everything about them. Think Oblivion and closing the 8 gates in a row, it just sucks doing it all at once.
-Tons of secret areas but are rarely worth finding them, oftentimes used a spell like levitate to find 40 coins which isn't even worth the cost of the spell.
etc...

reviewText:
To say I regret the time I spent playing Risen would be like saying the holocaust was a little unfortunate. If ever a game was created to frustrate and punish (not by way of skill cap) an rpg lover, it would be this game. Risen has all the appeal of dating a toothless Little Debbie taste tester without the great bjs or free snacks.  It boasts so many cool concepts and executes on NONE of them.  Easily one of the ugliest least enjoyable Rpgs I have ever played.
Making a list of pros for this game is next to impossible;  maybe the interesting creatures in the world could be appealing to some, but definitely not when weighed with all the filth this game manages to churn out.  The combat is complete trash, you button mash for melee and god forbid you try to use ranged.  No reticle unless you zoom and the zoom takes 2 seconds to focus. Now try to get a shot off while groups of melee  enemies rush your face.  Basically the only ranged strats consist of shooting before in combat and switching to melee (O don't switch weapons while zoomed cause it will stay there and u will have to manually zoom back out...derp) or breaking the stupid AI by diagonally strafing into enemies and shooting them when their character models begin turning.
The AI is laughable and insanely easy to take advantage of,  Running a group of enemies over tree roots and getting them stuck allows them to be easily picked off.  And again since most enemies are melee it makes it that much easier.  Enemies have one attack pattern that never changes, charge into you and do 1 of their often times 2 possible combos.  The game tries to mask this huge failure by making the difficulty extremely high.  If you're playing on hard enemies will kill you in a couple attacks.  Im perfectly fine with a game having a high difficulty curve...If it's fun (Dark souls).  This game is not fun at all.
While the game says it has character customization and varying skill paths it basically boils down to being a bandit or a mage both of which have as much depth as a mud puddle in July.  Much like the skills, the quests have different ways of completion that would appear to have morale consequences tied to them but in the end its essentially more gold for making the correct" decision and even if you completely screw over the npcs related to the quest  and they say they hate you
date: they will still interact with you the same way. The quests reminded me of an MMO
recommended: a whole lot of fetch and kill quests with almost no substance; given by countless npcs you will never care about.  Every npc has the same melancholy tone and you will remember none of them
hoursPlayed: much like your own character.  You can literally go into a town
helpfulPercent: beat them till their health is gone
votesHelpful: loot all their items
votesTotal: wait for them to get up and beat you to death (you dont die) and get up and keep everything.  Rinse and repeat. Such a well coded game.\nThe world is open for each map and you're free to explore as you like
votesFunny: likewise with quests you can pick the order of completion for many outside of crucial story quests.  This is a wonderful model for an rpg to have
commentsCount: unfortunately for this game the maps are bland and almost always dark.  There was no place I visited during my playtime that was memorable and quite frankly the game is ugly
column16: like early original xbox ugly.  It's only fair to note that I never actually beat the game even though that was my primary goal.  So it is possible that the quests might have started to pick up and became somewhat interesting
column17: but this in no way excuses the snore-fest that was the first part of the game.\nSo we have an ugly role playing game with terrible AI
column18: boring combat
column19: forgettable quests and a depressing cast of characters that only reflect how you will feel inside after you start playing.  The only way I would ever recommend this game is if it was at least 85% off and you have played almost every other rpg on steam. Piranha Bytes really dropped the ball on this one.  3/10 for this walking steamer."

reviewText:
First of all - I am a huge Gothic fan. I like the first two installments of the series (along with the Night of the Raven). I couldn't get over Gothic 3, Forsaken Gods and Arcania - they simply broke my heart.

Now, please, turn on this track before you start reading this review. I insist:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HLpvT97bQGk
Turned on? Okay, you're good to go.

Risen isn't a perfect game, but it's good enough for me. I'm enchanted with Gothic, of course, but that's a legitimate reason for me to like Risen. The game has many references to Gothic (familiar character names, bandit camp in the swamps, Harbor City, civil war, an isolated island with tense residents - it just makes you feel like in the two original Gothic games).

What can I say about graphics... I'm not someone who is familiar with the newest graphics. I played Metal Gear Solid 5: Ground Zeroes and I can admit that the graphics there are astonishingly beautiful. What about Risen? They're... different than that. That's all I can say. I just lost track and can't really tell a difference. I guess it might be safe to say that this game's graphics have aged somehow, but they aren't bad even for today's standards.

The audio is lacking in something - particularly Kai Rosenkranz's music (EDIT: actually, I just found out that Kai *did* compose Risen's OST - but it is different for some reason, so different that I couldn't even tell this was Kai's music indeed). This is the thing I miss the most. Kai really had a talent to create great, varying moods throughout the entire games with mere music. Once you feel at ease, at another time you feel tense, and at totally another time you feel grave. I would dare to call him one of the best composers, I would even dare to say he's better than Soule. Risen lacks this atmospheric music, unfortunately. It changes your mood subtly, but it simply isn't as powerful as it was in Gothic. Still, it has some catchy tracks, but you just can't really remember where they play after you turn the game off. Gothic didn't have that problem at all. If you did as I asked you to do - turned the Monastery track from Gothic II, it should have ended at this point. If it didn't, you probably have heard a large portion of it, or at least it started to loop. You can finish listening to the track, or simply stop it. Your choice. However you decide to do, please, turn this track on right now. I insist:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HjXZJ2ZY5og
The difference is obvious.


The gameplay is the most important aspect to criticize here. And here's the trouble. I cannot be unbiased. Like I said, I treasure Gothic dearly, and this game *is* like Gothic. You have many references to it (or just self-repeating patterns because of the developers' laziness - but it doesn't bother me, I like it). If you played Gothic, you'd have no trouble figuring Risen out, no walkthroughs needed at all. But if you're new to PB's games, then I suspect this game will be a challenge to you.
The island is small (about the same size as Khorinis). But it is extremely detailed. I couldn't find any broken places with floating trees, rocks or other, similar stuff (hi, Todd*). The world is semi-open - just like in Gothic. It doesn't feel like you're crawling through dungeons and linear pathways. Of course, that means the world isn't randomly generated on the spot by the game, and everything is pre-defined, which can be either a pro or a con, depending on the perspective (this makes this game's replay value lower, I guess).
The fighting system reminds me of Gothic - you can't just click mindlessly, but time your clicks and have a tactical approach to fights. If you are stupid, you can be level 15 and get beaten by a pack of wolves. But if you're smart, you can defeat a tough, armored guy equipped with a decent sword when you are a fresh castaway. Your combat ability depends mostly on your skill as a player, not on your characters' stats. Of course, even the best players will probably lose against some opponents if the odds are impossible enough.

It is a specific game. Not for everyone. But still, is any game suited for everyone?

All in all, if you are a fan of first two Gothic games - do get it. I'm sure you won't regret it.
If not - get a demo and try it. Or simply ignore it. Maybe it'll appeal to you, maybe not. You will have to try it out yourself.

My personal rating: 8/10.


(*Todd Howard, CEO of Bethesda Softworks, famous mostly because of The Elder Scrolls series and Fallout 3 and New Vegas)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B7trmEmI5Js

This is a third-person RPG scavenger game. The reason I only have 2hrs listed is because this game was in a package deal and I got a refund because the others weren't working right. I got this game on disc when it first came out.

You have two main choices in the game. This will efect somethings you'll get or lose. Access to the other camp which making them enimies. You  have other choices you can make as well like what will your guy be? Fighter, wizard or theif. You'll be able to  get what you need with some running around and planning.

From the little bit I've play the game seems to be the same. Some games are dumbed down and/or made easy. Which if true which means I can recommand it to those gamers who don't like easy games.

reviewText:
Giving this 6.5/10.

I'ts playable to end with patience. While it justifiabley deserves more, I was hit with a bug that prevented me upgrading my swordfighting.

The game itself is quite brilliant. Controls are easy, the scenery's good, and the story is easily interesting enough.

However I was hit by two things that slowed the game down badly. Early on, my recommendation letter was not accompanied with directions where to take it. I wandered for at least eight hours. Eventually I searched online and found where to go. Second my close combat was hindered by my inability to advance my sword fighting stats.

Another of my grumbles, is that about a fifth of Risen, is spent in the dark. Medieval torches did little to help, and you have to drop them to battle, if your're using two hands. In there I was locked in battles with lizard warrior foes that took me hours and hours and hours to defeat. Shame. [Plus the disgusting noise the lizards make - urghh. It's like the sound of regurgitation and growling mixed.]

Many seem to complain that Risen is slow, but if you're patient you have masses of fun.

reviewText:
This game is everything Gothic would have been if it were released fifteen years later. I recommed it to whoever enjoys the adventure/fps-combination and want a bit more challenge to the fights than pumping attack key. The game tells you to save often, and in truth you should do it after every battle; if you get caught with your pants down, it's all over in seconds.

Graphics and audio is very good, even if my machine gets overheated quick on 2880x1620. Thankfully the game looks very good at lower resolutions, and I haven't had any game crashes so far in about 20 hours played.

I'm using an ASUS laptop, i7 @2,20 GHz, 8 Gb RAM, SSD disk, Windows 8.1

reviewText:
I didn˙t heard much of  this game before I played it, however I have to say that it`s really worth the time. It has a very long storyline, with wide side-mission list. The combat sometimes can be buggy, and annoying, but once you get into it, it's not a big deal.

The ability to choose between factions is great, however I only played it through once, so I don't know how much difference does it have between the playthroughs. The skills are mostly done right, you can't be in all role in the game, however I think that playing as a swordsmen is much more difficult like as an archer, or mage.

I'd give the game a total of 8/10, so I think it's really worth a shot. You can get dozens of hours into it, and if you're a fan of RPG-s, you possibly won't be disappointed, if you don't take a faults of game too seriously.

reviewText:
I try to love this game. Yet I just can't.

I had already played it some, the leave it right after exiting the game. But, after noticing the sequels for Risen, inevitably I told myself,  Maybe the story is good, since it spawned up two sequels.  So I gave the game another try, searching for  any  redeemable quality.
I have to say I really like the alchemy system, smithing, and how the game make use of magic. Creating scrolls yourself and whatnot. It is a hassle, but a rewarding one. I like it how you can use a 'Joke' spell to make up with a character you previously angered. That's about it, I guess.

Moving on. Halfway inside the main quest, I sighed in despair. Realizing that I don't even  care for the Main Character  for me to start caring for any its secondary characters. And that's a huge flaw, considering I play RPGs for its main content: the storyline and a good vast of characters to help strengthen it. Though some RPGs are lacking in story, they backed it up with an amazing combat system, for instance. Or its huge amounts of loots. Risen lacks both.

So, unless you're a die hard of fan of RPGs, with sole purpose in life to play every RPGs out there is in the face of the earth, give it a try. But I can't recommend it in full price.

But I'm only a voice, telling my own experience with the game.
And then is heard no more; it is a tale
Told by an idiot, full of sound and fury,
Signifying nothing.

reviewText:
Failed expectations
I really love Gothic series, so my expectations concerning Risen were very high. And for about 15 hours of the game everything was 'about' right. But the rest - boring, tedious at times, especially after chapter 2. I will try to explain why:
- Story. Of course Gothic wasn't perfect by any means in this regard, but Risen is way worse. I don't want to give spoilers here, but i felt as if I were doing one big Fedex quest, which was lame and uninteresting. Maybe studio ran out of ideas and had to make something generic...
- There's nothing much to do after ch 2. Befeore starting ch3 you can easily complete nearly every side quest in this game, leaving you almost nothing after then (apart from main plot). In both GI and GII it was completely opposite, world was changing and giving you new challenges.
- City is totally dull. After you complete quests in ch1, there is rarely a reason to go back there. And city itself is minimal version of Khorinis.
- NPC are uninteresting. There are mainly just a quest givers, without a flavour to them. Compare this to wide range o Gothic characters...
- Chapter 4, with all this tomb raiding and boring (like designed for mobile devices) boss battle is a fatal end to end this game.
Really, in the beginning I was (positively) shocked - Hey
date: it's good pold game again' feeling. But as I mentioned
recommended: the rest was getting worse the more passed. I played for nearly 40 h
hoursPlayed:
but it took me about 6 weeks to end this. Normally it would be two.
There are pros of course:
- Graphics is very good
- Interface is better thought than in previous PB games
- Combat system seems to be better
- It made me want to play original Gothic again

It is by no means a bad game

reviewText: Good game but the combat drags it down quite a bit. Maybe it's because I am missing something here, but the combat is not engaging and deep as the developers seem to have intended. Instead it's annoying and repetitive. The rest of the game is quite well done.\n\nThe world itself is very well crafted and cool. With many different environments and creatures to fight, it's fun to explore. Along with that which I very much appreciate is that there are areas where you will be very much under powered and will be squished like an ant if you venture there. Instead of the hand holding and area leveling that most other games in the open world rgp genre employ.

reviewText:
OVERALL: 4/10
===

Pros & Cons
+ Pros +

+ Good level of interaction with NPCs
+ Choices you make in the Storyline will drastically change where you end up and what quests you do
+ Good stealth mechanics


- Cons -

- Combat system is completely broken (there will be a special section down in the review where i will explain this in detail)
- Miserable variety of equipment and loot
- Character leveling system and development are aswell completely broken (details later)
- The class you develop is bond to certain questlines you may or may not follow (details down aswell)
- Miserable graphics even for the year it came out
- Interaction with the game world is non-existent
- Characters are anonymous, uninteresting and inexpressive. It looks like talking to (badly) animated tree stumps.

===

Special Section - About Gameplay, Combat System and Character Progression
This is an extraordinaire section i made just for THIS review, in which i will explain to you, esteemed reader, the abyssal flaws i have described up above.

1. Combat System: Risen's combat system, regarding melee mostly, is such a mess i have rarely witnessed in my whole gaming career. First of all, attack patterns, movement animations, speed, parry system are wholly flawed beyond repair. Enemies can dodge your attacks which is fine, but they can aswell attack just after they dodged, in the span of a tenth of a second, which you cannot do at all, and then repeat their attack animation a random number of times consecutively, this can very certainly end up with your character being 1-shotted by an unstoppable series of attacks you cannot parry, for there is a little delay between when you are wounded and when you can again parry; this delay is larger than the delay between the enemy attacks, so you cannot do any action while under a barrage of attacks.

Secondly, facing multiple enemies is totally unfeasible: you can focus your attention on just one direction while attacking, your attacks are bond to follow that direction as long as the animation goes on. This means, you cannot, say, hit one enemy with a slash then hit another one near him and then a third one. Attacking one enemy leaves you totally exposed from all other directions, from which enemy can attack you like i described before. Player cannot even lure single enemies, as triggering combat with one will very likely trigger the whole enemy field and drag you to a multiple combat you have zero chances to win, unless said enemies are very far below your level.

Third, animations are clunky, unresponsive and generally really messy. Players will have trouble timing attacks and also to spot when an enemy is going to attack, since there is no pre-attack animations, nothing, enemies just stand there then attack instantly without any little notice, and then return to their idle animation.

2. Character Development: Oh boy here we go. first of all your class is bond to the storyline you might want to follow: for example if you choose to be a bandit, you will not be able to be a mage. This because when you level up, this game has no normal RPG style level up system, but instead gives you Learning Points, and nothing else. These points can be used at specific trainers around the world to improve your Statistics or Abilities. Fact is, certain branches of the Main Quest will allow you only to learn certain classes' skills as i said before. This limits the experience a player may want to pursue heavily. Also, trainers cost Gold, each ability you learn costs gold, and also Statistics cost gold, other than Learning Points.

This system is totally failed and limits the developmetn of your character by a lot.

===

Final Thoughts
Risen could be a nice game with its setting and storyline, but many gameplay-breaking issues and bad art direction flaw this game beyond salvation.

I do not recommend this game at all, unless you just want a world of pain and suffering.

reviewText:
Here is a list of reasons why I do not recommend this game
1. Without adjustment it doesnt seem to work on windows 7
2. The autosave suddenly saves over your tactically placed manual save.
3. Your character is super sluggish when reacting to button prompts.
4. In addition to #3 the actions taken by yourself and NPC's once engaged are almost comical in speed. Making it impossible to respond to anything. Best part is that when you hit someone, they dont get stunned, they just hit you back.
5. On top of being sluggish it is nearly impossible to gauge distancing in this game, you can suddenly just get hit from enemies.
6. If you accidentally steal an item, that person and all his buddies want you dead. period. for what seems to be the rest of the game, this makes for a game- over like result when it autosaves right after it happens.. Great idea developers.

I can handle harder gameplay, but bad gameplay is another story..

I will probably give this game 1 more try, only because I hate wasting money on things. I really want to like it, but I am finding myself trying hard to try too, which isnt a good sign. Spend your money elsewhere.

reviewText:
I'm a fan of RPGs of any age but Risen, unfortuantely, has to go on my 'no fun to play' list. I had hopes going in it'd be fun, given it has a different style to classic action-RPG mechanics but most of these differences were very frustrating because the game itself does an EXTREMELY poor job of, at least, making you aware of the changes. Did not make for a good start for a Let's Play series on YouTube.

The graphics and audio have aged well, though the characters are pretty bland and uninteresting for the most part... but I admit I haven't gotten far in the game. The lack of presence of the story also does not encourage me to keep playing. Without a solid anchor to the narrative, I can't really immerse myself into the game. For games like Skyrim, it works well because they hook you into the story within the first couple of hours but Risen just doesn't get the hooks and alludes to no concept of the story you're suppose to be experience in the first part. You're just some dude who got ship-wrecked and, for some reason, has to pick a side without knowing what the hell is really going on. (Which I am aware you find out later)

Most of the controls I had to learn through trial and error, since the tutorial parts are either bugged or just stop after teaching you how to open your inventory, looking at the character screen, and how to swing your weapon. Things like blocking and parrying are fairly easy to figure out but dodging took some effort as well as how to upgrade my stats, since leveling up doesn't seem to affect them at all, which would have been nice to be made aware of at the start and I still don't think I understand the whole system revolving stats aside from blowing gold on trainers... who seemed rather expensive in the early stages.

Then there's armor... probably my biggest issue with the game. The fact I didn't find a piece of armor at all but I was practically tripping over weapons was quite confusing. I honestly thought I had broken the game or was just being an idiot (I like to think I'm semi-good at video games, especially RPGs) but when I researched several walkthroughs on the game, it became very clear you can only recieve armor under particular circumstances or paying a lot of gold if you manage to find a vendor that's got a set so... that was a huge 'NO' in my book. Not asking to have everything I kill drop items like a pinata but there should have been as many options on armor availability as there were weapons. Gathering the gold was an unneccessary and annoying side track that ate into time I could have spent progressing the story... but then some of the enemies towards finishing up joining The Don were barely survivable unless you have impeccable block/parrying skills (which I did not).

Though I, personally, would not recommend this game to anyone and have much more confidence in other RPGs from the same time that would be enjoyable... I'd say give it a shot if you're interested and draw your own conclusion. I just found this title to be no fun and that does not give me hopes for its two sequels.

reviewText:
Not surprising when you search for Risen on google the biggest amount of threads revolve around combat in this game and there appears to be two schools of thought about this: Some consider it rewarding once you learn it. others consider it just plain bad.

After playing this title for some time it really is the second opinion that wins. 'But it's good that it's hardcore, i like it that way' some say.

No it's not.

Play Inquisitor or Dark Souls if you want it tough. Plain bad does not equal hardcore. Not with the amount of good alternatives Steam provides today.

To put it bluntly: If you are considering to buy this then ask yourself - are you ready to spend lots of time playing out a luke-warm story that is constantly hampered by bad combat and aging graphics? I say don't bother.  I spent almost 5 hours on this and did not get anything out of it. Nothing. no memorable places or events or anything. Could not possibly be more grayer game start. And i really don't give a damn if 'it gets good later'. I seriously doubt it after seeing how the dialog and quest systems work in addition to just plain bad combat.

reviewText:
For the first 24 hours or so of playing this game, I was sure that I'd be giving it a positive review if for no other reason than because I had spent nearly all of my free time playing it since I started. By the end of it the best thing I can say about it is that I'm still interested in trying Risen 2.

The tone of the first half and the second half of the game is alarmingly different. From when you first wash up on the beach with a fellow castaway who proves entirely irrelevant to the point where the main plot is actually explained to you, the game spends its time impressing upon you how much of a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ the island you arrived at is and how the population is the exact mix of workshy, cynical and desperate to put you in a position of solving all their problems for them out of sheer exasperation. It's a fairly interesting setup that manages to keep the usual RPG fetch quest formula while also completely justifying it and making sure it never feels like irrelevant busywork.

The second half of the game is killing lizardmen in a dungeon crawl.

I'm barely exaggerating. Chapters 3 and 4 of the game are spent almost entirely in one dungeon or another, fighting wave after wave of lizardmen. While the early half of the game was fairly restrained in its call to violence, to the point where I don't think I killed more than a dozen humans over the entire course of the game, limiting combat mostly to fending off ill-tempered wildlife, the latter half has you cut down hundreds of lizard men.

And to be clear, there's a good reason the combat was so restrained in the first half - Risen's combat is AWFUL. Take Dark Souls, remove the stamina bar, but also take away dodge-rolling, slow block speed to a crawl, and only give the player five armor upgrades over the entire game. I admit with zero shame that I eventually got sick of this and activated godmode at around 2/3rds of the way through Chapter 3. The combat is tolerable in controlled doses, but the second half of the game is almost nothing BUT combat, which the system clearly wasn't designed with in mind.

A few more warnings to keep in mind should you try it for yourself:
- Don't sell your scrolls, at least not the Telekinesis, Levitation, or Nautilus ones. Despite the ostensible freedom of the RPG mechanics, most of the 'puzzle' mechanics blatantly only have one solution, that being magic. Maybe one in five will give you a problem that can be solved with a bit of athleticism or archery.
- Speaking of, don't bother with archery. It doesn't do much damage and the entire group will immediately bumrush you after the first arrow. Additionally, the ranged weapon skills only upgrade draw and reload speed in 10% increments, with no further abilities.
- The jump mechanics are quite possibly the absolute worst I've ever seen in a game. In addition to being just really floaty, Risen's edge physics are absolutely terrible. There were roughly a dozen instances where I'd climb up or dump down from a ledge only for the game to be unable to decide whether I'd landed on the ledge or was supposed to slide down, and instead of pushing me down like most games do, it simply left me hovering in the air forever, forcing me to either load a save or restart the program entirely. Unfortunately the game requires you to climb or jump more than a few times to progress, so all I can recommend here is to save often.

While the overstuffed combat and the tedium of the second half thoroughly alienated me, I enjoyed the game's opening hours well enough that I'm still going to give Risen 2 a try, but personally I'd say this is one to skip.

reviewText: Ugh, I don't know how this game got so many positive reviews. There's just one word I can use to describe it: boring. You start out on a beach, wander around for a while, sleep in an abandoned shack, and eventually find a bunch of people who ask you to do their menial tasks. I played almost 7 hours, hoping something interesting would happen. After completing a quest whose objective was to hide out in a barn, I lost all interest. The combat is frustrating, the loot is boring and rare, the story is dull, the monsters are unremarkable, and the game just overall put me to sleep.\n\n2/10 would not find beer for town drunk again
