reviewText:
Well guys, as far as an RPG goes this one's a bit messed up. First, lets get the things they've done okay to well noted down: The pace of this game very good but the story is about average, Cliche, but better than some. This is NOT a short 10 hour romp of patheticness that RPGs made now are and the leveling/advancement of your character are at about where you would expect. In addition the world looks amazing especially for when it was made and it doesn't hold your hand as much. NO LOAD SCREENS! Well, Almost none, you WILL be hitting quick load a lot, but I'll get into that later. For the world, story, and looks I'd give this game a 7/10. But, like nearly all seemingly good things this is completely ruined by the following:

It commits close to, if not ALL of the unforgivable combat gaming sins:
-all enemies physical attacks are normally twice as fast as yours.
-The game randomly slows your attack to 1/10th your normal speed, giving all enemies
around you free hits as you can't get out of the animation, thus killing you by default through
no fault of your own.
-Your enemies, including wild animals, can parry your parries, but you as a player can't even
with max skills.
-All enemies can attack and hit you instantly, you cannot. Your sword can literally be
connecting with them in your attack and the enemy will often instantly get a super powerfull
atack in that is so fast you can bearly see them move,
doing massive damage to you. You as a player are not capable of this.
-Dodging is of no use as your enemies can track you through it perfectly and hit you anyway. You as a player can't
track or hit, even by chance, a dodging enemy.
-Enemies have unlimited numbers of attacks they can string together while the player, even with the skill that
supposadly allows such, cannot.
-All enemies recover from recoil 3 times faster than you do.
-Enemies sometimes become invulnerable and cannot be harmed, this is also not fixable by reloading a save and
requires the game to be restarted.
-Your character is sometimes spun around by enemy attacks and of course, you are not able to do this to them.
-If you save after you have an enemy's attention any reload of that save will load that enemy within stricking range of
you and attacking, no matter where they were when the original save was created. This renders such save unusable
as you end up dieing the moment the game loads every time, no matter what the cercumstances before the save.
-All enemy melee weapons have greater range than yours no matter what. Enemy has a dagger and you have a two
hand sword? Their dagger out-ranges your sword. Even animals out range your weapons with their horns and teeth.
-Enemy gaurding has a good wide range of defense from the front, But you only have defense for a tiny sliver of angle
that leaves you pulling your hair out as you watch blades swing THROUGH your shield to hit you.

So, all in all I'd give non-combat parts of the game a good 7/10. It is a good story and environment but it isn't anything we havent seen before and the story is cliche. But for combat I give it a definate 0/10, that's right, an actual ZERO out of ten. Combat is so buggy and un refined it renders the game completely unplayable a lot of the time and melee combat is based purely on you getting lucky. So unfortunately, I have to give an overall score of 3/10 and can't at all recomend this game to anyone who doesn't want massive levels of frustration.

reviewText: After playing Risen for less then 5 hours I encountered no less than 3 bugs that just ruined the experience for me.\n\nI'm talking about the kind of bug that you can only fix by entering console mode and typing strange commands to undo events or retrigger scripted ones. Bugs like I talked with X before talking to Y and then I don't have the dialogue options needed to complete a mission anymore". Or I slept before talking to X and he disappears
date:
so my only option is to respawn him using the console.

But equally impressive was how easy it was to find out the console commands needed to redress each situation. Apparently these bugs are so common that there are thousands of forums and threads about them. And I read about so many other bugs while looking for my solutions that I just lost all desire to go ahead with the game.

My conclusion is that this game's scripting system is completely broken

reviewText:
Easily the worst free-roaming action RPG in all of creation.

This game fails at good gameplay, fails at good storytelling, and fails at a balanced experience.

But worst of all, and this is unforgivable, it fails to get you to care.  Not even fun as a lark or a challenge.

You cannot wander twelve steps without finding an enemy who has the exact color pallette as the enemy you were just facing, but deals one-thousand times more damage for some reason.  And that's not an exaggeration.  There are enemies almost immediately adjacent to areas you are properly leveled to be in who can one-hit you.  You have no way of knowing this or how to tell them apart.

reviewText:
I know it's not good to transfer one's initial frustration into a review, but I'm at a complete loss about this game. Either I've grown too old and casual for such games, or there's something wrong about it.

Its technically openworldish nature goes in stark contrast with limits and shackles pushed onto you in such a strict manner that it simply feels shocking. Yes, there are no corridors and no narrow passageways between sky-high rocks, but instead you are still separated from your whereabouts by invisible walls of creatures way beyond your level, prices way beyond your possible earnings, and quests way beyond your capabilities - even if you are exactly where you are supposed to be gameplay-wise and story-wise.

In RPGs of the kind, I usually act alone in the wilderness, learning stuff, training myself, exploring locations and occasionally going to towns for some quests and business. That gives me the feeling of freedom I need and keeps me comfortably independent from my surroundings. To keep things simple, I'll just say that nothing of this is possible in Risen, and I feel very frustrated about it.

One of the most painful limitations for me is the inability to develop the character by means of practice. To learn skills and advance your stats, you must get training from other people. To get training from people, you need money. To get money, you need to fulfill quests. To fulfill quests, you need... to learn skills and advance your stats. I must say, I became tired of running in such circles.

Maybe it's all personal, and maybe I'm overestimating some stuff, because I'm going unusually emotional about writing this review, but at the moment I don't feel like I want to continue this game.

reviewText:
I should've listened to my skepticism, considering this game was made by the same developers that made Gothic series. This game is exactly like the Gothic games, except in slightly better graphics. Tedious menial tasks such as harvesting, collecting, and finding n number of some item are back again. No story hook whatsoever. It's just a random island your character finds himself in after being washed ashore. To add to this, the character's walking speed is very slow and the map isn't detailed enough and shows no landmarks, making exploration a real chore.

There are a lot of items to find and the combat is semi-decent, but nothing in this game really stands out. Everything has been done before by other RPGs and done better.

Some of the dialogue is not bad and can be kind of witty, but some of the voice acting isn't all that great, especially the main character, who hardly puts any emotion in anything he says, and this is coming from someone who is rarely ever picky about voice acting in games.

Some NPC and enemy A.I. is a bit strange too. I got into the arrogant guard captain's house and stole stuff from his treasure chest right in front of him and he did not bust an eyelid. I then took a mug of beer from his table and he got all pissy at me all of a sudden. Another enemy was doing a decent job stopping a few feet away from me, letting me shoot them with a bow, then to chase me for a few steps, and to repeat the same procedure till he was dead.

If you liked Gothic games, you'll probably like this one too, but it's way too slow paced for me personally. The most fun I got from this was when I decided to stop doing any quests and to simply mess around. Piranha Bytes just keep rehashing the same old boring formula in every single game, and until they make something new and different, I don't think I'll be buying any more of their games.

reviewText: A plodding RPG that'd be quite good if it wasn't for it's shocking back-and-forth slow pace and a phobia to 'lewt'. The open-world nature of the island you're ship-wrecked on does lend itself to bouts of exploration and it's easy to disappear off the beaten track when something sparks your curiosity. A mountain of side-quests and above average combat will take your mind off the shallow crafting system and keep you busy but careful who you align with - annoyingly, your class/skills can be affected by the path you choose.

reviewText:
Agonizingly slow and painful start, enough to discourage anyone from keep going. After that excuse of a beginning it gets better. In fact, it seriously flirts around the idea of being 'Gothic' worthy, but then it collapses under a pile of badly written fetch quests that exist throughout most of the campaign, and an even more tasteless plot. If that wasn't enough already, the devastated remains of said tortured game get utterly crushed by a gigantic anvil: The horrible final boss fight --basically it's a subpar Crash Bandicoot-esque boss arena--, and thus, leading to an abrupt ending that does not make up for the time you've dedicated in the whole process.

Tl;dr.: +1 Strength +1 Strength +1 Strength +1 Dexterity +4 Wisdom +4 Wisdom +4 Wisdom +4 Wisdom +4 Wisdom +3 Wisdom +3 Wisdom +4 Wisdom +5 Strength +10 Experience + 1 Dexterity

4/8

reviewText:
Where do I start with a game like this?

I guess the first thing to do is denounce any notion that this is an open-world game. After you break out of the linear tutorial, you can't exactly go out and do your own thing. High-level monsters litter all but a select few paths, and the only way to figure out whether or not you can pass is to fight these monsters (and surely get your ♥♥♥ kicked).

So, of the few paths you can take, you'll end up in one town or another, with different factions, altough really, they're all the same: masculine-looking people who hate you. Almost EVERY person you meet is a total ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥. I understand wanting to have a game where you're not instantly likeable, but this is way beyond that. I guess I understand it, though, since a thumbtack has more personality than whoever the hell you play as. He's boring, he's constantly finding ways to ♥♥♥♥ people off, and his voice acting is poorly-delivered.

Shaping and growing your one-dimensional protagist is no fun either. EVERYTHING in this game can kick your ♥♥♥. No matter how decent the combat is, if you end up fighting a group of more than two enemies, even if they're weaker, you're screwed. And for how good the combat is, you can't easily heal during battle, so if you don't land your blows right away, you're dead. If you wander off into the woods and into a pack of wolves, they'll chase you and kill you.

So, that limits your area of fun to the towns. Not only do people hate you and constantly crap on you, but the few quests you can actually figure out how to get are your simple MMO get me 50 of something" or "go here and kill this thing" quests. Not to mention there are no landmarks
recommended: or any other mechanics to help you find the places these people want you to go. Why should I bother finding these quest locations if I'm just gonna get wrecked by a camp of gnomes or a wolf that happened to be guarding the tracks?\n\nSo
hoursPlayed: you can't do quests. Maybe you can go out adventuring on your own somewhere? Hah! Your character is about as devoid of adventuring skills as you are. You know nothing when you begin

reviewText: The game is pretty good at the beginning.  I enjoyed the scenery, game development and how the game progressed.  Then I started nearing the end.  You have to jump on different ledges in various caverns to progress.  The game fell apart.  I was saving before every jump because I wasn't sure if the game would glitch or not.  Then the levels became convoluted and confusing with having to go back and forth to find something that may or may not have been there.  The fun aspect of the game became frustrating.  If the glitches were fixed and maybe a map that would be created as you explore (instead of not-exsisting for some areas) it would be nice.

reviewText:
This game felt weird, the combat is wonky, to the point that at end game I lost ~75% hit points against a mob that I could one hit. EVERY mob in this game has the dexterity, dodgy-ness, and deflection skills of a ballerina and ninja love-child who was trained from birth in the art fencing.

The beginning of the game was entirely too hard, and grindy, I was without even simple armor for the first 25% of the game, then once you get through that, the loot seems to just fall on you at a rediculous rate.

The voice actors all sounded like they were experiencing the worst hangover of their lives whilst reading their lines. This really broke the immersion and crippled what could have been an incredibly well done story.

The graphics were okay and the scenery was pretty, but there was this super annoying grainy" overlay that covered everything
recommended: playing this game felt like a chore. 3/10 Buyer beware

reviewText: What can I say? It's basically Gothic 1, just with some better Graphics. The main problem I have with this game is, that it's a little bit bugged which ain't much of a problem. Personally this game didn't caught my attention, but rather left me frustrated about the fact that if I get knocked out by a NPC, my Hero throws away his weapons and I have to search them again (IF you find them...). Also the combat system is kinda weird, because it locks onto enemies, but yet you can accidently aim at another enemy, which is in a battle of at least 3 people or so, a bit annoying. Also it seemed to me, that every enemy was way stronger than I was and killed me with 3 hits or so. Blocking didn't do the trick sometimes as well. The map isn't really helpful either or the journal for that matter. It shows you where some people are, but sometimes it didn't said where I would have to go, meaning I have to find my way by simple guessing, to complete a quest. I do not recommend this game, because it didn't entertained me or caught my attention long enough to oversee the flaws this game has.

- Over 60 hours of Immersive open world gameplay.
- Alter the destiny of the island by the actions you take.

reviewText:
Risen is an open world third person rpg which has you running around a small island with some caves and some enemies and one major town. You will be doing several fetch quests and you will be fighting a very limited variety of enemies for most of the game.
I did not find the fighting system to be fun.
You can't leave the island or go in the water.
After spending 70 + hours in this game, I've decided that this experience ends up feeling like a low budget, boring, extremely limited, buggy, and repetitive third class waste of time.
Lots of weed use though, that's a unique plus.
The entire Elder Scrolls series does this game style on a MUCH more interesting and larger scale; there is no point in wasting time here in this basic world of Risen when you can spend your time in a much better and far more impressive world such as any of the Elder Scrolls series. It just makes sense to spend your free time playing the games that have done this gameplay concept better.
There are many bugs too that I ran into often.

Here are some of the bugs I have come across:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=410634790

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=410634758

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=413582949

Take your money and time elsewhere, such as Elder Scrolls: Morrowind, Oblivion, or Skyrim.

reviewText: Please don't let the 77 Metascore fool you. This game is very underwhelming. You will dredge through the game, not knowing at any time what is really going on, while being swarmed by knee-high monsters that any RPG would rate as cannon fodder. but not in Risen. In Risen, you will fight for countless hours against pathetic, poorly-designed enemies while using a mind numbing combat system. If the later installments of this game have improved, I wouldn't know.\n\nI invested enough time into this game to actually write a review and downvote it, and I almost never go out of my way to not recommend a game. Please, save yourself the wasted time. Play any Elder Scrolls game, or Dragon Age, or even go old school and play Baldur's Gate or something.

reviewText:
RISEN
A fairly shallow and flawed third-person action RPG.

Rating 4/10

Risen came out in 2009 around the same time as Dragon Age and in comparison it looks and plays like a game that should have been released in 2003. For an RPG it gets a lot of the basics wrong, there is very little in the way of character creation or character choice. You play an uninteresting potato head looking protagonist with no back-story or motivations other than you've been ship wrecked on an island in an unknown world. There are three different ways of playing your character, as a mage, warrior or hunter. You are able to level up various skills such as strength or sword fighting through training that can be purchased from various NPCs around the island. It's incredibly simplistic and offers no real choice.

The NPCs littered around the island in small limited number of locations are lifeless and bland. The voice actors sound as though they have no interest and everything is delivered monotone which is strange considering the vast talent they've arranged for the voice actors such as Andy Serkis and Lena Headey. It also doesn't help that the character models look awful like they've come from a game made in the early 2000s. I struggle to think of a single interesting character in the game and even the characters with some promise like Patty have woeful looking models which undermine the character.

Combat is a clunky and frustrating experience, based on timing and luck. Enemies enter into attack cycles, you have to block until they've finished their cycle and it turns into a repetitive and boring game of waiting. When there are three or more enemies it becomes quite hard as every hit you take breaks your current attack and being hit from all sides gives you very little option other than running away. Whilst combat becomes easier as the game progresses it still remains an incredibly frustrating experience.

The menu and item system seem to have been an after thought. There is no limit on how much you can carry, at all, meaning I was running around carrying 500 heavy weapons. With no inventory limits it means you give little thought to what you loot as you can take everything. More often than not I just spammed the loot button on enemy bodies without bothering to check what they had. Added to this the serious lack of weapons and armour, I came across 4 sets of armour during the game and you don't get the first set of armour until at least 7 or 8 hours into the game. There is also no reason for half the items you pick up, food and frying pans are all meaningless after the first few hours. All you need are potions are spells and the small number of items needed to make them.

There are some positives, the environment looks pretty good with a great Island setting and the story moves along a fairly quick pace with a couple of great side quests. However it's not enough to make up for all the games flaws which outweigh what little good there is.

reviewText:
Risen is an RPG that continues to follows the same theme as the Gothic series. The story is generic high fantasy with forgettable characters with even more forgettable quest and storyline. Like most of Piranha Byte's work in this genre, the combat is abysmally bad. Risen would've been at the very least acceptable if it wasn't such an unnecessarily long winded and bug ridden game.

Risen is chock full of bugs, many of which will break quest line. I personally couldn't finish this game without the use of console commands to fix certain quests. The game becomes an absolute cluster poop once you hit the volcano mid game as important quest npc's get stuck or the lever that was suppose to open gates stopped working. Console commands can fix some of these issues, but the customer shouldn't have to resort to cheats to proceed in a video game.

I can only think of one other RPG with combat that is even worse than Risen and that is Gothic 1. Coincidentally that was also made by Piranha Bytes. The combat in Risen is reliant on a very bad target locking system; it locks on the closest target, and you cannot change targets manually. This means that if a enemies groups up on you, you are going to be swinging at the air as the bull poop lock-on system wildly changes targets automatically. You will then proceed to die as enemies stun-lock you in to oblivion.

The game store page indicates that this game is 60 hours of game play, which is mostly correct if you consider that 40 of those hours are spent wandering aimlessly to find the next place to turn in your quest. The directions in the dialogue are outright terrible and the lack luster quest marker made the questing even more tedious and boring. Now compound that with the fact that Risen is comprised of mostly fetch quests and you have a recipe for one of the most boring RPG experience ever.

Risen is basically Dark Souls with none of the awesome or the refinement in game-play.

reviewText:
Risen...where to begin? This is going to be long so hold onto your ♥♥♥♥, I recently replayed Risen and wanted to give it a review.

Picking up from Gothic is hard since Gothic is Gothic and Gothic is unmatched. Saying that though, Risen *kinda* managed to do it in a way that brought Gothics scope back to earth, in a very good and very real way.

The thing is, Gothic was such a wide and non-linear game that it was incredibly hard to actually understand what you had to do (As opposed to Dragonage, where even a baby can understand the objective), the world of Gothic was designed with no key objective in mind apart from the user exploring the world, and even though Gothic dated, in time, it's experience never did and it remains one of the best RPG's of the last 10 years.

Risen, like I said, brought that wide, vast experience, and although it cut out most of that stuff out, and boiled it down into a 35-something hour experience? it was still fully open, and still had callbacks to it's forefather. Is that a good thing? I'd say so, if you'd ever played Gothic.

The Good? What Risen was good at were key, small things, like guards robbing you if they defeated you in combat, decisions that actually affected you (More on this later), factions that actually mattered (Kinda), forced content tracks (Monastery) that weren't droll or felt artifically enlongated AND optional content tracks that had abundant (Often overpowered if un-nessicary) rewards.

There were items in the wild that meant something, mysterious subterranean caves overrun by creepy, overpowered, grimdark nightmare-fuel creatures (You think I'm kidding) with some of the best weaponry in the game. quest NPC's were 99% killable, some quests were unavoidable where others were completely optional but had great reward.

you could fight and kill some of the best mobs in the game if you employed their own traps and tactics against them in the early game, and these feats felt fun.

But that's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t! those things happen in the exact same way in Skyrim

Awesome game, it's a little difficult at first, so just be cautious and patient, even the simplest of enemies will kill you if you're not careful.\n\nGreat gameplay. great quests, interesting story. A+

This is the best RPG I've played in a long time. It's nothing too over-the-top, however the legnth and fun gameplay of this game has made it very addicting and exciting to play. The graphics are beautiful and the story is fantastic. The game has a very smooth, yet simplistic combat system aswell; how you perform in combat determines if and when you die or not :P

The only flaws I've seen are:
-The Save/Load buttons are too close to eachother (F8 and F9) and a simple misspress can make you loose a lot of gameplay time.
-Be cautious when on the roofs of the Monestery housings, you might get stuck x3
Fun and challenging. 7/10

I used to own this game some time ago, so I've decided to pick it up on steam. I didn't have much time to play it since, but I still love it. It might not be a worthy successor to Gothic, but it's damn close. The Island feels alive and you won't find an empty place on it. The enemies are challenging, but not invincible. All in all, if you've enjoyed Gothic, you'll enjoy Risen.

When I was a little kid, my friend borrowed me Gothic. When I started playing it, I was astonished by the beautiful graphics and that undescribable atmosphere... Risen as well as Gothic was created by Piranha Bytes. Even though how ancient are these games, you stick to the story so much you have to play it until the bare end. Sure some can't stand the graphics. But if you're used to these oldies, you'll love risen.
10/10. True successor of gothic 3.
Gothic, Gothic 2, Risen, etc.  Loved all these games despite their flaws.
Playing this game has made me truly appreciate tactics in active combat and you will too.

This is a criminally under-rated game. Yes is has its short comings but it really shines in the fact that it doesn't hold your hand through the whole game and lets you figure it out on your own giving some feeling of accomplishment. The game is made for people that like a good challenge. It's very hard and easy to die but as you grind your way to better skills, do enough quest for better armor it works out a lot better. You have to earn whatever you get. I think the biggest thing that  detracts from the game are the bugs where you get stuck in walls trying to climb etc. so save often. The game is solid, has different paths and many hours worth of game play. I took the bandit path and didn't use magic so it was more work but rewarding. You can learn many different skills but i found being a master thief to be the most fun. I highly reccomend this game if you're not looking for a generic walk you through everything kind of rpg.
Awesome game I must say, fighting gameplays are realistic but a little bit boring..\n\nP/S : Too much realistic though, everytime I die I have to spend money to get weapons.

Some say it's the follow up to Gothic (I-III NOT the Tales of arcadia one!), I say it's Gothic without too many bugs. In this open world roleplaying game you start off as a stranded noname and work your way up to save the world which is being attacked by creatures out of long lost ruins risen from the underground. Besides it's beautiful scenery and a worthwhile story the game offers a character system and an inventory with infinite space (great for looters like myself). Although the combat system has been overhauled in comparision to Gothic, it's still a bit clunky and fights against animals can be a bit daunting, as attacks can't be blocked. Nevertheless I would recommend this game to all Gothic and roleplaying fans who are searching for a game with a nice setting and a not too shabby story including the hero with no name"."

Pretty cool. A bit slow though, mostly because every battle has a good chance of killing your character, forcing save reloads until you win. There's kind of a weird balance in this game where you're both underpowered and overpowered at the same time, mostly because good weapons are readily available while armor is rare.

When you get right down to it, this is the game that Morrowind wanted to be--an island adventure in which every corner of the map is packed with content, rewarding players who take the time to explore. The combat system's a bit counterintuitive at first, but it's ultimately quite fun once you figure it out (and it's nice to play an RPG where you can actually beat monsters much higher-level than you if you can figure out a proper strategy.) My only complaint is that there's only one playable avatar available--the option to play as a woman would have gone a long way towards compensating for the male-dominated cast.\n\n(Protip: join the mages. Ice magic is awesome.)

An incredible adventure by choices you make by talking to the charcters nad quests, amazing atmosphere and extreamly ditailed weapons, monsters, humans, everything.\nI can't wait to finish it and start again.
gothic!
An amazing RPG. Extremely fun. Who needs quest markers. Personaly I think the combat in this game is a bit better than Skyrim. That means this game should be in your inventory within 24 hours.
So far I enjoy this game. I like the combat system and I love item collecting.

I enjoyed this game all the way through. From the developers of the Gothic series... which you can tell because it's pretty much like those games but modernized. The combat is improved, and the graphics are very much improved. For 2009 this game looks amazing (with the graphics turned all the way up). The game isn't perfect... there are some glitches, but they're mostly minor and don't affect gameplay much. A big chunk of this game is about exploring. Most of the game you're exploring a huge island, and later parts of the game you'll be in ruins and underground caves. Most of the enemies you kill stay dead, but at the beginning of a chapter some enemies do respawn. The combat is challenging, but satisfying. The story starts alittle dull, but by the end it's very interesting. If you're up for a challenging Action-RPG, and your computer can handle it, then I highly recommend Risen.
If you are looking for a great RPG in a more classic way, with no flashy kill cam moves"
date: as seen in todays' most games
recommended: look no further. The world is breathing
hoursPlayed: colorful and with great variety. And so is the quest system. Few of them follow the standard gather and kill pattern. Most are connected with each other and do a good part in taking you along your adventure
voteText: exploring the whole island of Risen. With no doubt the best part of Risen is the epic sound track. It's on par with background tunes from the elder scrolls
helpfulPercent: perhaps even surpassing it

commentsCount: but go on. You won't regret it!"

First impressions might be a little iffy due to the first chapter being pretty boring, but after that the game picks up really nicely and the fight system is really good. Highly recommended for fans of Western RPGs.
Huge action RPG Adventure with tons of things to do  alot of interaction with npcs and story
Povinost pro fandy serie Gothic. Piranha Bytes holt umi...
I waited a long time to finaly play this game. I wasnt excactly floored after playing the demo. But man did it really pick up in a hurry. It was one hell of a fun rpg to play.

reviewText: good
Interesting story althought the game crashes alot which is a bummer.

It a good RPG game, its rather interesting, but you have to play for quite a bit to get into the story. At first this RPG seems quite dull, but as it evolves it reminds me of Gothic quite alot and that's a game I enjoy.

I give this game 7.5/10.0

As one general positive point, it is an interesting RPG with good quest designs and combat mechanizm, and as a general weakness of this game is that the character is not customizable (as in charasteristics), combat is challenging (which can be a problem for beginners and people who refer to take it easy, but others, like me, find it somehow enjoying and frustrating at the same time), and finally after playing a game like Skyrim or Fallout 3/ New Vegas, I got used to the fast travelling after you visit a place, this game offerss teleporting stones in/after chapter two but they can only take you to specific places (this is a bit weird and means quite a bit of walking is involved).

In conclusion, its worth a shot for the story and another unique adventure to experience. EvilBorn Out!

From the moment my character washed up on the beach(es) theres several beaches in this game. Good game but takes quite a while to get used to the combat system.  The story and gameplay makes up for it though.  It's one of them games that you ragequit when you die, but yet you go straight back and load up your last quick save!

Pros:
Good storyline and well thought out quests.
Fun thief route if your that way inclined
Combat becomes increasingly better
Graphics and music are quite nice

Cons:
Limited armour upgrades (Quite linear)
Mobs don't respawn, one kill only.
Takes a couple of hours to get in to the swing of things.

8/10 :)
Start with Skyrim, dial back the graphics a few years, shrink the world, remove armor, add combat from Dark Souls... BAM!  Risen.
Best game RPG after Gothic 2 ( Only bad rep from people that haven't played or liked Gothic series ) !!!!

A great RPG with 2 different parties a player can side with by their own choice : The Don's Bandits or the Inquisition.

This game allows the user to perform many side quests along the main quests, has a large but not too large world map which one can explore and a variety of items such as plants and foods (almost anything one can think of: apples, bread, eggs and even potatoes!) one can use to create potions and cook to produce foods.

The graphics may be of a slightly lower quality than most games we have now, but it's nothing shocking or unusual since it is one of the older games (although it is still quite good).


I definitely recommend this game
Love this game . so much to do and all the npcs feel alive.\n\nI beat a guy down and stole his stuff and he hated me after.
Highly recommended if you don't mind a difficult game. Don't expect handholding.

Just played through this game in a couple days... It's addictive... The game starts out, ok, very nice graphics, nice dialogue, nice animations very polished game. The voice acting was very good IMO, especially the smith oscar in the bandit camp... Loved the interaction he offered. I didn't care for the story, it felt cheesy and kind of stupid, the main character was likable and simple. The world itself is very frustrating because simply there is way too much ♥♥♥♥. What I mean is there is a very large amount of confusing forrest and little nooks/crannies. They jammed a lot of stuff in a small island. It's hard to navigate through parts of the world and until you get a map from Nelson the cartographer, you are completely oblivious to where you are. You can find multiple teleport stones which there are 14.... That's outrageous... Wayyyyy too many teleport stones. It makes the play impatient and rushed. Overall, I enjoyed the game but I felt myself very annoyed with how simple the main story was. It was very much, go get these items and come back to me. Oh ok you got them all??? Now we need you to go get these items and come back. That's literally all the game is. The crystal disc gathering, the titan armour gathering and then the boss fight. All the inbetween stuff is great but the main quest was lacking creative depth... go fetch quest are boring and feel like chores rather than gaming experiences... Overall I'd say 7.5/10 I wouldn't replay the game and honestly, at the end of my bandit camp playthrough, I just used console cheats to experience magic because I didn't want to play through again all of the go fetch quests. The magic is good in the game I would rather have done magic, the bandit character isn't developed at all and the crossbow is AWFUL. Even headshots do almost no damage to strong enemies, the titan crossbow does less than 1/10th health damage to a lizard elite.

Risen is a very intersting game. It feels strange at first and combatis very cumbersome, however if you stick with it for a littel while it realy grows on you and you realise how deep the game actually goes. This is a game where plowing through the first hour or so is essential to really appreciate the rest the game has to offer. The graphics are nothing to shout about and the games doesn't have any stand-out original features. But fans of the Gothic series will feel right at home with this brilliantly complex and rewarding RPG. Give it a chance, at first it seems horrible and heavy, but after the first hour or so it really shines as a deep and fun experience.

Pros:
- Lush, densely packed environments to explore
- Tactical combat with strategy
- Very addictive gameplay

Cons:
- Controls feel heavy
- No controller support
- Takes a while to really get into anything interesting

Very gritty well rounded RPG! Kind of reminds me of The Witcher and Dragon Age in parts, although it's just short of being as good as either of those titles. Still a solid game which I strongly recommend to all fans of RPGs!
Great story line and good gameplay. It is a bit buggy but you can still beat the game with a big smile.
Best RPG ever.

reviewText: good
A very interesting and refreshing game. Kind of old school and open world like but with limits. Nice story and nice setting.

The this I like best about this game is the calm and relaxed atmosphere. This makes it a real enjoyment to play. I have played through it around 3-5 times, and I still feel that I could play more without getting bored.

The combat system might be a bit difficult to master. In order to be real good you'll need precise timing of your attacks. The weapon classes are very different. I must say that it's much harder to go with staff fighting than using an axe.

I can't remember encountering any gamebreaking bugs. Only one I can think of, but I would look at it as more of a glitch than a bug.

Wow, good game. The combat actually requires skill to play and isnt all based on your characters attributes. This game has a good open world feeling to it with lots of side quests.. i only just started chapter 2 and ive been playing 25 hours. So far I am pleasantly surprised.
A difficult, strange but overall good game, very Gothic like.
Very good, albeit difficult, RPG. Very much like Gothic, sort of a spiritual successor (since Arcania was ♥♥♥♥).
Very good Gothic style RPG with good amout of challenge and variation. Thumbs up!

If you like those 3rd person, Action/RPG, Bethesda type, collect-anything-that-isn't-nailed-down games, then you'll love this.  It's got some bugs even with the unofficial patch, the combat system takes some getting used to, and there could be some more general polish to some of the other game mechanics, but I still highly recommend Risen if you dig these high exploration games.

I'd characterise this as clunky but good. Parts of it are better than any other RPG I've played and other parts are well, less good and very occasionally down right infuriating. Still the clunkiness adds interest. If you want something that offers something different from the typical thoughtless rollercoaster gaming experience then Risen is well recommended because it certainly offers that.

The combat for example is genuinely challenging and engaging. The first time I beat an ashbeast, after avoiding them as impossible walls of angry death for the first half of the game, was a genuinely great moment. The emphasis on flanking and positioning is good but makes it all the more infuriating when a glitch allows a mob to clip through the mob standing in front of it to land an impossible blow. The feeling of powerlessness at the start of the game is palpable which is something that a lot of RPGs lack. Transitioning the character from badass warrior to a bigger badass warrior is not really much of a progression. Risen on the other hand transitions the character them from being some half dead shipwrecked numpty with a tree branch to being a convincing badass warrior and it feels great.

The characters are similarly a mixed bag. Several of the characters are genuinely interesting and, dare I say it, funny. On the other hand some of them are laughably awful. Sara for instance, the first character you meet, turns out to be one of the most paper thin RPG characters I've encountered. It seems obvious she was meant to have a significant character arch or perhaps be the alternate main character but she ends up being basically dumped after the first fifteen minutes. That there is also no option to play as a female character seems a shame considering that the main character isn't exactly a well fleshed out consistent personality who would have had to have been completely re-written. There aren't that many female characters in general and none of them really stand up. It feels like someone wanted to try to be progressive but others on the team must have been complete Neanderthals. Patty is almost good but then at one point gets pointlessly damselled in a totally out of character fashion. The female bandit captain was a good idea but rather undermined by being an almost completely reactive character who doesn't actually do anything except talk to the main character and stand about cooking... yeah... oh and she only has power by virtue of being married to the bandit leader. Sadly the gender politics of this game ends up being on average typically rubbish.

The story is coherent, just about, but don't expect any real ending. My guess is that something more ambitious was planned but ended up getting cut. There is a gimmicky final boss that is actually easier than most of the normal fights and then a fade to black and a voice over. Not much is actually resolved though and not much has actually being accomplished as far as saving the world is concerned. Ah well, it is better than the first Borderlands, just.

It isn't a game for everyone and it isn't a game for people who aren't willing to tolerate its quirks but if that sounds as appealing to you as it does to me then you probably won't be disapointed.

Are you looking for those oldschooly RPG kicks that only one German developer can provide? Look no further - here's Risen. The first two Gothics were better, but this is still a VERY solid game. Yes, the graphics could be better and the controls more responsive, but, you know: Who cares. It's a Pirahna game.
Its a bit slow pase and a bit harsh in combat difficulty but still pretty good if you get the hang of it.
An excellent RPG that will keep you playing through the end.  4.5/5 stars.

The aspect of the citizens of this world carrying on with their daily lives makes your actions in their world all the more relevent. I'm now on the european rpg bandwagon, if not the wagon master himself!
10/10. True successor of gothic 3.

This is a criminally under-rated game. Yes is has its short comings but it really shines in the fact that it doesn't hold your hand through the whole game and lets you figure it out on your own giving some feeling of accomplishment. The game is made for people that like a good challenge. It's very hard and easy to die but as you grind your way to better skills, do enough quest for better armor it works out a lot better. You have to earn whatever you get. I think the biggest thing that  detracts from the game are the bugs where you get stuck in walls trying to climb etc. so save often. The game is solid, has different paths and many hours worth of game play. I took the bandit path and didn't use magic so it was more work but rewarding. You can learn many different skills but i found being a master thief to be the most fun. I highly reccomend this game if you're not looking for a generic walk you through everything kind of rpg.
So far I enjoy this game. I like the combat system and I love item collecting.

reviewText: Great story line and good gameplay. It is a bit buggy but you can still beat the game with a big smile.
Best RPG ever.

An unusual game, that feels a little dated today (5 years down the line). It is by no means a spectacular game, but it has a gripping charm, and urges you forward every step of the way. Its combat is off putting at times and the voice acting is pretty rough but the small things make up for its faults. It give you the choice to do almost exactly as you please and doen't hold back with the number of things to do. The HUD is minimal and it all feels organic in the way you're given and can access information and it's a nice change. This review feels a little like the game it self, confusing. You don't know if it's brilliant or rubbish.
Great game from the creators of the Gothic series.

When I was a little kid, my friend borrowed me Gothic. When I started playing it, I was astonished by the beautiful graphics and that undescribable atmosphere... Risen as well as Gothic was created by Piranha Bytes. Even though how ancient are these games, you stick to the story so much you have to play it until the bare end. Sure some can't stand the graphics. But if you're used to these oldies, you'll love risen.

If you like RPGs, and can get past the AWFUL combat controls, you'll enjoy Risen. I liked the story, the way they integrated the class choice into the narrative, and the overall freedom of choice. The graphics are fine (nothing spectacular, though), and it can run in older boxes.

If you enjoyed the Elder Scrolls series, this is a game for you.  I'd say the combat is mediocre and only half the enemies are challenging (then again I played it on Normal difficulty because I'm soft haha).  I'd recommend Hard difficulty if this isn't your first open world RPG. The protagonist has next to no background or personality, except when he's being sarcastic.  His sarcasm is quite funny, but hopefully whenever I get around to playing Risen 2 they will consider adding more depth to the main character.

A few things I would have changed is adding bosses in some of the ruins/dungeons you explore.  The only actual boss was the final one (which was slightly disappointing in terms of mechanics, but visually it was badass).  The ability to forge not just weapons, but chest and head equipment would have been nice to have.  If there was a way to go about that, I didn't discover it.  My final problem was the auto-targetting feature which would often get you killed when fighting off a mob of enemies at once.  You do get used to it, but it was frustrating every so often.


Overall i thoroughly enjoyed my first playthrough. Story is the most important aspect of an RPG for me, and Risen delivered.
The first half of the game was a little slow, but it was building up the backstory of the island and it's inhabitants.  The second half of the game is when the plot thickens.  I enjoyed the lore and look forward to what the devs accomplished with Risen 2.
This game is very fun and hard which adds to the fun of the game.

Risen is an RPG that to me feels like a neat mix of Skyrim and Dark Souls. The world is plentiful to explore and there are boatloads of secrets and quests. The game's combat can be a little unforgiving, with some enemies beating the hell out of you regardless of level.\n\nOverall a grand experience. You'll be immersed, you'll have lots of exploration, and you'll probably like it.
Got killed by a pack of boars 5 times in a row. 10/10
Reasonably decent
a good RPG, decent mechanics, graphics are outdated.\nmaybe boring on the long run, but if you like RPG games go for it, it's good!

Really tough to get started.... have to be hardcore RPG fan.... sadly I am and I really kinda like this game, fighting is hard, I mean you think you can just left click but some actions by mobs are so random its hard to counter.... Save alot and get ready for lots of frustration and dying... if you can get past that thought game is pretty ok... a 6/10

Nice RPG in the 3rd person. Rewards exploration, so do not be in a rush, look around your surroundings before moving on to the next area, it will help. Kinda old school, so if you are looking for the latest and greatest, you might not enjoy, but if you like the classics and taking your time planning your character, this might just be for you. the price sure won't break the bank either ;)

I have never finished this game nor I ever, most likely, will, but still I return to it time to time.\nI can give only one reason why I do it, because the world feels alive. because most NPCs have a routine and this game has much spoken text, if you chose to talk to NPCs. Not much for todays standards, but enough for me for a few hours time to time.

Another open world, Gothic/Two Worlds lookalike. As you get stranded on an island filled with emerging old crypts and temples, you work your way through the different hierachies and choose the path you wish. Although they all give about the same outcome, the characters/skills variety are worth messing around with. Loyalty or thievery, that is the question that most struggle with in this game. A well made world filled with people and animals of all shapes/sizes. Enjoy a walk through the depths of the swaps, the grassy hills of the monastery or join the militia/Thieves.\n\n10/10 for ingenuety and open world. Choices affect you the right way in here.

An unusual game, that feels a little dated today (5 years down the line). It is by no means a spectacular game, but it has a gripping charm, and urges you forward every step of the way. Its combat is off putting at times and the voice acting is pretty rough but the small things make up for its faults. It give you the choice to do almost exactly as you please and doen't hold back with the number of things to do. The HUD is minimal and it all feels organic in the way you're given and can access information and it's a nice change. This review feels a little like the game it self, confusing. You don't know if it's brilliant or rubbish.

I bought this game in the Humble bundle and have only just got round to trying to play it but for some reason i cannot seem to get past a blank black screen after the initial 'Risen' logo. I get steam to check the files and it keeps saying 1 needs to be replaced each time i run it. I even did a complete new installation and it still does the same thing....When i press the windows key during the black screen and try to reopen the window i get a debug error message saying i have a memory dump issue....now i have no problems with any other game at all nor does my computer have any issues either. I just want to play the game as it looks sweet as!

My first outing, I chose the Don's side and had to work my way up through the ranks of a dismal group of the Don's not-so-merry men out in the swamp.  A rather unsavory bunch, and some miserable questing, till I lured a monster down from the mountain into camp who dispatched my most hated rival for me (to much maniacal laughing on my part).  Then I made my way to town working for the Don and played that side till I was able to meet the not-so-evil Inquisitor and actually started poking my nose into ruins - though killing monsters was still tough-as-hell.

Then my computer exploded.  Damn, no save in the Steam cloud for this old game.  So I started over, this time starting in the town and working towards becoming a mage.  The story plays totally different this time, so I don't feel like I'm covering the same ground.  Want to get good with the spear, but my sword and shield are still better, so I'll stick to that for now.  When will I ever be able to cast a spell, I wonder?

Risen is tough.  Loot is ultra minimal, especially armor, and you have to earn what there is.  If you like terrorizing the populace like a Skyrim Sithlord, this is not the game for you.  Levelling up doesn't mean you get new skills, it just means you have the potential to get them;  you still need a trainer and you need to pay them.  The character models and animations are primitive.  You can't choose your character's race/sex/anything;  you've got the standard Ewan McGregor model, and that's it. Combat is probably trickier than it needed it to be.  I still don't know what spells can really do, even after playing for more than 30 hours.

But the game is addictive.  The environments are compelling.  The town, especially, is beautiful.  Solid voice acting all around, and the dialog is well-written.  The overall story is interesting.  The music is soothing and suits the game very well.  And beating an antagonistic monster NPC - either through guile or battle - is very satisfying.

I don't know if I will ever finish Risen.  It is a hard game, and there are so many Steam games vying for my attention these days.  But if you see it on sale (and there will likely be more once Risen 3 is released), I highly recommend it.  It has gotten me interested in trying out the Gothic games as well.

At first I didn't care for this one, came back a few months later after playing Two Worlds II and I couldn't seem to put it down.  Clunky but brutal combat, just takes a while to get a hang of it.  The quests and overall storyline were rather engaging and fun.  Pick it up in a bundle if you get the chance.

In short: Good RPG with a bad first impression

Cons: The game has a bad first impression because it does not explain itself all that well, so if you are new to Piranha Bytes games you might end up googling a little, wich is always anoying. The other thing is that, in the beginning you are weak as a kitten and the world is very harsh place,but in time however you will become more powerfull and exploring the world will get easier. That for some people is a gamebreaker, or atleast a turn off. Games usually are easy at beginning and get harder by the end, but here the game is hard at beginning and gets somewhat" easier towards the end. Atleast if you use your experience points right.

You see

reviewText: Patty was gorgeous.

Just finished it.

Positives:

- Good quality vs price: Well worth the money
- Mostly had fun playing through it.
- At one point the sword upgrade was broken (I had an item which boosted the sword by one and apparently there's a known bug for this) but there is an easy to access in game cheat system... which also greatly helps once you're bored with the game and just want to get through it (for me that was after about 32 hours)

Negatives:

- A little too long. It feels like they intentionally make you run around the world a lot to lengthen the game and at some point there are so many strong enemies that give you so much XP that you start wondering why you did all the small silly quests for 100 XP, when killing a single lizard gives you 320 xp.
- Quests malfunction sometimes and then become unclear.
- Not as polished as say SkyRim, sometimes quests aren't really clear. Little side quests do not show up all the time. Then again the level of polish it has is to be expected of an older game.

I used to be a big fan of Gothic I and II with add-on (I did not find the third part as addictive as previous, mostly due to irritating bugs like disappearing essential NPCs and boring storyline). Several years later I decided to buy Risen I and II from Steam sale off (I have heard of the series before but I was not especially interested - I do not know why). Looks like I hit the bull's eye.

I hate cRPG games which force you to have a party of dumbasses following your steps (if I want play with team I rather play some real RPG game or MMO). My limits are Neverwinter Nights, Dragons Age and Fallout -like teaming games, so this game is simply what I expect from good cRPG before I even start it. I can be a great warrior but also a decent thief with alchemy passions – because for hell's sake - am I a hero or not?

The main storyline is very addictive and your actions like joining either of in game factions have visable further consequences. Most of quests have a few ways of completing them. You need some item from a greedy folk and have no money to pay for? How about doing him a little favour, or simply pickopet or beat him to uzurpe it? Even when you are older and simply do not have that much time to hang around in game world and stick out from main story, devoting precious hours of your life, this game just force you to. Not because you must but because you want. The world of game is full of locations which are little stories themself, pressing your inner curiosity to check out as many of them as you can, turning your mind into the mind of the rough world scavenger, slashing and bashing his way through skeletons in searching for forsaken artifacts.

I have played a lot of cRPGs in my life, as well 'high-ended' as indie or rogue-like productions. But there are just a few that I have found as interesting as Piranha Bytes productions. Honestly I have not found ANY cons in this game yet and there is over a dozen of hours I have spent playing it. Maybe later I will found some, but for now – this game is pure perfection for me.

Almost at 40 hours at the time I've written this review and I know that I could easily get another 10+ hours out of it. I find this game refreshing. Although it's a bit older, it has some qualities that new games could take a lesson from. There's a lot of optional ways to play the game: Optional quests, the way your character develops both in skills and via the story, and the way you interact with different people all shape the game you're playing.\n\nIf you're into games of the Elder Scrolls series then you'll most likely enjoy this. Be warned though, it's a little tougher than those games! Once you become used to the combat and grow with experience you will begin to enjoy the difficulty of the game and at the same time you'll curse it once you're killed in one hit...Thank you auto-save!

Let me begin by saying that this game will not start you off with any experience or skills. You need to be aware of that before you ever start playing. You start out shipwrecked on an island wearing only the ragged clothes on your back . This game comes about as close to a real life scenario as you can get.

If you got shipwrecked in real life with little to no combat experience or training it would be just like Risen. You have to find weapons, potions, food, and all the other stuff by exploring, learning to fight and getting experience killing various beasts and monsters.

I love the fact that as I get more skills, training, better weapons and experience, that the game gets better. I was getting frustrated with getting killed all the time, but I slowed down and took my time to build up my skills. Pigs and wolves used to eat me for dinner all the time. Now I can pretty much just smack them down and get on with my travels.

The game is really hard for the first ten hours or so, but it gets a lot better and easier if you stick with it. I have seen a lot of reviews talking about the horrible combat, but most people judged it on the early game play. You have to train and level up to get more attacks and better combat.

If you stick it out and train enough, you will get some very effective and proper attack and parry sequences to use. You also have to have enough strength or agilty to make the combat more effective and deadly. Like in real life, you don't just know how to sword fight and use weapons. You have to train and practice non-stop to get the skills and experience. There is a reason people have to practice martial arts for years before the can call them selves a master or to even be above the novice levels of skill.

When I first tried Risen right after it was released I hated it. I finally came back and tried it again and now I love it. It's not a perfect game, but it is a solid 8 out of 10 for me. There are some flaws, and some things annoy me, but so does real life. The length of time the game gives you: and the feeling of growing and getting better and progressing make it all the more enjoyable.

One of the only things I did not like was the lack of armor and clothes. You get a pretty fair amount of weapons, but the armor is pretty limited.  I can overlook that in light of the fact that in real life you would not have an endless array of new outfits to find. You get a lot of chances to get better weapons, both from enemy drops and vendors. Weapons are pretty satisfying, they fit with the game progression and leveling up.

After finally finishing my first play through, I can see why this game has such a dedicated following. It's called a cult" game on some forums

The game is that good that I want to fully experience every twist and turn from all the different progression/character lines.\n\nThe fact that you have multiple ways to approach all the quests

reviewText:
A good spiritual successor to the Gothic games, which I don't play nearly as often as I'd like.

Combat is excellent, and like Gothic, your actual skill at it means more than anything they give you to improve it in the game.
You also get 3 combat paths in the main story, so you can play through its rather quick campaign multiple times without getting bored.

The only downsides to this game are the sparse character models, and that it's a little short, with no DLC.

reviewText: Risen is a fun RPG from the makers of the original Gothic series.  It's very similar to those games, so if you like open-world RPG's with interesting back-stories and off-the-beaten-path gameplay, I'd definitely try Risen.

This game is quite the hidden gem of modern RPGs. The only way to describe it is if Morrowind, Two Worlds, and Lost had a Devil's threesome, and Morrowind got pregnant, this would be the miracle spawn.

The graphics and gameplay are almost on par with Skyrim (and while I'd still consider Skyrim the better of the two, this is a close second). The story isn't nearly as strong as what you'd expect from an Elder Scrolls game... probably because it's not (which the good combat mechanics will immediately give away)... but it's certainly not bad, and the voice-acting, the dialog script, and pretty much all of the character interaction in this game will keep your immersed.

Playing this game is like rediscovering Morrowind. Not in the sense of it being Morrowind, because it's not, but in the sense of figuring out the unique game mechanics as you play and being surprised and elated with every new bit you come across.

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

I played the game because I was a Gothic fan, my review will be based on that assumption. You are still a nameless hero and there are some key areas that shine in this game in relation to Gothic, while others fail to compare to what I found to be the best RPG of its time.

PROS
The world is vastly open and completely explorable, there are a number of things to collect for alchelmy, smithing, and food preparation; the puzzles are a good balance of challenging yet not impossible; you're character is yours: meaning just because you like bows doesn't mean you are limitied to them you can dabble where you like. Some additonal pros are the ability to use two handed weapons as one handers with enough skill and

CONS
Money is easily found and little needed. Skill points quickly becaome irrelevant, you don't need to level most things and frankly theres not a lot to level up anyway. Choices for guild are very limited: Don or Inquisition with little difference between the two.  THe game is significantly shorter then Gothic. Little to no replay value.

In conclusion, Risen is a decent game, and I did enjoy playing it; however it is no where near as good as the Gothic series. I would recommend that you play this first and then work your way up the Gothic series, so your games get better as you go.

My first ever A-RPG was Fable: The Lost Chapters. It is one of my favorite games to this day. This game is better than that. I'll do good/bad lists as I prefer to read them myself as well because they are easier to read:

Good:
+ Voiced protagonist unlike many other RPGs
+ Lots of dialogue options
+ Quality voice acting
+ Choices matter increasing replayability
+ Idyllic setting, relaxing soundtrack
+ Atmospheric environments, good lighting effects unless you tinker with brightness settings
+ Burried treasures
+ Challenging combat, limited and expensive gear
+ Tomb raiding, dungeon puzzles, traps
+ Immersive character building. Your hero doesn't learn stuff out of nowhere after levelling up, i.e. distributing skill points. Instead you gain LP (learning points) which you can spend at trainers (NPCs who teach you stuff).
+ Class system doesn't restrict your play style too much. You can be a dumb bandit but still can use magic via scrolls if you want for example.
+ Reminds me of other A-RPGs I enjoyed such as Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning, Witcher 1, Fable: The Lost Chapters and Dark Souls.
+ Fast travel system.
+  I love some of the animations in the game. Particularly lizardman idles where they snap a fly in the air while standing around or look around like a paranoid or shaking their head. They are strangely cute and realistic <3

Bad:
- No respec system in the game (can be done via console commands, cheating)
- Sometimes you might wonder why you couldn't complete a quest. There is no handholding to the point you start wondering if the game is bugged but most of the time it is not. You probably need to talk to somebody but you haven't.
- Some may find the combat too difficult at the start.
- No sprinting. You can get Speed magic which is basically sprint which should have been in the game from the start instead of a spell which you can get quite later in the game.

Of course recommended. 9/10. A must play.
Played for about 15 minutes, killed some gnomes, got some gold, got a level, and then immdediately got pitted against a boar that chased me to the beach and then killed me.\n\n10/10

I can't seem to get this game to run properly.  I notice most people do not have this problem and seem to love the game, so perhaps I have THE ONE THING on my machine that it isn't compatible with, or something.

I spent hours attempting to solve a flicker problem occurring every time lightning struck (which is about every half-second when the game starts), and an associated striping problem, and managed to get it reduced, but not eliminated.  I won't go into what all I did, because there appears to be a 99% chance, or better, that you won't have that issue.  I figured, at this point, that I would just play through and try to get to a non-lightning scene.  Then my first conversation froze up, and I just gave up.

With the monstrous number of games I have on Steam, it will already take me about 10 years to play them all, so I'm just not going to spend this much time trying to fix this one.  I was considering buying the other two Risen games (they're on sale this week for reeeeeallly good prices), but I'm going to assume the same team made all three and just NOT.

For all you people who do get to play, I'm sure you'll enjoy it.  :)

Perfect for those that wanted a new Gothic game but didn't care if it was set in the Gothic universe or not. There are lot of similarities, which is all well and good, especially since it is from the Piranha Bytes, the developers of the first three Gothic titles.
Essentially this is an open world exploration RPG in which you don't know what you're doing unless you really focus. The map is quite large without and fast travel and you don't always know where you are. You can walk into an area where you are too low a level for, it's easy to not have the correct skills for a quest and be completely boned. In a nutshell, this is a game that is out to get you like a Dungeon Master that holds grudges.

PROS:
+ Good graphics for the time
+ Physics are fun to play with
+ Easy to get your butt kicked
+ Big map
+ Tons of things to do
+ Many skills to learn
+ Great for Gothic fans
+ Fun to talk your way out of situations

CONS:
- Steep learning curve for people who have never played a Gothic game before
- Sometimes feels more RPG than action, which does not feel right for the series
- Some humans refuse to die
- Perhaps too easy to die
- Too easy to wander into high level areas when under leveled
- You always seem to need a higher skill level than what you've learned, no matter where you go
- Combat controls too clunky
- Leveling up and learning skills is a chore, an EXPENSIVE CHORE
The fighting style is a really big pain in the ♥♥♥. Enough to make me uninstall the game. It's a shame because otherwise it seems nice on a lot of aspects.

Game is a 6/7 out of 10, not the best RPG i've played, The main charachters voice acting is poor, and annoying, The exploration of the map isn't overly rewarding as you'll late have to trek back there for a quest, so may as well save the time. And the story line is filled with monotanous fetch quests... Not sure why I like this game at all, probably for the sheer mention of magic, Titans, and Gods, which i've yet to see any of by the way...

If you like those 3rd person, Action/RPG, Bethesda type, collect-anything-that-isn't-nailed-down games, then you'll love this.  It's got some bugs even with the unofficial patch, the combat system takes some getting used to, and there could be some more general polish to some of the other game mechanics, but I still highly recommend Risen if you dig these high exploration games.

I'd characterise this as clunky but good. Parts of it are better than any other RPG I've played and other parts are well, less good and very occasionally down right infuriating. Still the clunkiness adds interest. If you want something that offers something different from the typical thoughtless rollercoaster gaming experience then Risen is well recommended because it certainly offers that.

The combat for example is genuinely challenging and engaging. The first time I beat an ashbeast, after avoiding them as impossible walls of angry death for the first half of the game, was a genuinely great moment. The emphasis on flanking and positioning is good but makes it all the more infuriating when a glitch allows a mob to clip through the mob standing in front of it to land an impossible blow. The feeling of powerlessness at the start of the game is palpable which is something that a lot of RPGs lack. Transitioning the character from badass warrior to a bigger badass warrior is not really much of a progression. Risen on the other hand transitions the character them from being some half dead shipwrecked numpty with a tree branch to being a convincing badass warrior and it feels great.

The characters are similarly a mixed bag. Several of the characters are genuinely interesting and, dare I say it, funny. On the other hand some of them are laughably awful. Sara for instance, the first character you meet, turns out to be one of the most paper thin RPG characters I've encountered. It seems obvious she was meant to have a significant character arch or perhaps be the alternate main character but she ends up being basically dumped after the first fifteen minutes. That there is also no option to play as a female character seems a shame considering that the main character isn't exactly a well fleshed out consistent personality who would have had to have been completely re-written. There aren't that many female characters in general and none of them really stand up. It feels like someone wanted to try to be progressive but others on the team must have been complete Neanderthals. Patty is almost good but then at one point gets pointlessly damselled in a totally out of character fashion. The female bandit captain was a good idea but rather undermined by being an almost completely reactive character who doesn't actually do anything except talk to the main character and stand about cooking... yeah... oh and she only has power by virtue of being married to the bandit leader. Sadly the gender politics of this game ends up being on average typically rubbish.

The story is coherent, just about, but don't expect any real ending. My guess is that something more ambitious was planned but ended up getting cut. There is a gimmicky final boss that is actually easier than most of the normal fights and then a fade to black and a voice over. Not much is actually resolved though and not much has actually being accomplished as far as saving the world is concerned. Ah well, it is better than the first Borderlands, just.

It isn't a game for everyone and it isn't a game for people who aren't willing to tolerate its quirks but if that sounds as appealing to you as it does to me then you probably won't be disapointed.

Are you looking for those oldschooly RPG kicks that only one German developer can provide? Look no further - here's Risen. The first two Gothics were better, but this is still a VERY solid game. Yes, the graphics could be better and the controls more responsive, but, you know: Who cares. It's a Pirahna game.

reviewText: A fairly decent adventure game with open world. The difficulty curve is fairly tough at the beginning as the world doesn't scale much. So you struggle at the beginning but it gets easier as your character gets stronger (be prepared to save and load a LOT).  It is fun though, and has interesting plot. Although you can build your character however you like to a degree
date: plot directly prevents you from doing some skill combinations. (For example, some skills can only be taught by some people who are enemies of other people who teach other skills). As a result, sides you choose will significantly impact your play style. (Some things you can work around a bit, others not so much). As such, the world, although fairly open, feels like a world with it's own limitations... not arbitrary limitations, but the world feels solid. I suggest playing it.

reviewText: This is a good 3rd-person RPG. It's quite immersive and you can really get sucked into the events going on and interactions in town. It's a fully open world and you're free to explore at your leisure. I'm in about 50 hours and I'm about halfway through. My only gripe is the combat system, which can be a bit cumbersome to fight.

Hi, I do actually have more play-time as I also own the game off-steam -2 playthroughs.
It's a game in the tradition of the Gothic series as they had to switch the name for trademark reasons so you have a traditional enjoyable RPG where you slaughter lots of animals for their meat and experience. You do quests and join one of three factions (bandits/inquisition/order). You can roam semi-free across the island though you will be insta-gibbed if your equipment isn't good enough for some places. The faction you choose kinda determines your class as it limits your skill trainer choices just like Gothic 1&2.

It's a good RPG and while it has its design quirks and odd bits the exploration is fun. Don't expect a deep story. You slay stuff, get better, explore a cave, find some ring, sneak and plunder. Side quests, main quests, finish. Also has crafting, alchemy, pickpocketing, locks and all the RPG standards. Tried and true formula but fun to play.
This game is very fun and hard which adds to the fun of the game.

Many consider Risen to be the true Gothic 3, and it's easy to see why. The game looks beautiful, plays well, and integrates many concepts from the Gothic games (multiple factions, all with good and evil sides, a focus on realism, tricky combat, and strong characters) all without the bugs that plagued the later entries in the series.\n\nWorth a play if you've finished Gothic 2 and want more of the same, only shinier.

Amazing game, combat is engaging and challenging, make a wrong move and you're going to die. I'm liking the story and love the main character, he's just some guy who snuck on the wrong boat and is now casted into this mess. Along with that the island is very pretty and lovely to explore. Has become one of my favorite RPGs and I certainly recommend it.
Great rpg hard game good story

I played the game because I was a Gothic fan, my review will be based on that assumption. You are still a nameless hero and there are some key areas that shine in this game in relation to Gothic, while others fail to compare to what I found to be the best RPG of its time.

PROS
The world is vastly open and completely explorable, there are a number of things to collect for alchelmy, smithing, and food preparation; the puzzles are a good balance of challenging yet not impossible; you're character is yours: meaning just because you like bows doesn't mean you are limitied to them you can dabble where you like. Some additonal pros are the ability to use two handed weapons as one handers with enough skill and

CONS
Money is easily found and little needed. Skill points quickly becaome irrelevant, you don't need to level most things and frankly theres not a lot to level up anyway. Choices for guild are very limited: Don or Inquisition with little difference between the two.  THe game is significantly shorter then Gothic. Little to no replay value.

In conclusion, Risen is a decent game, and I did enjoy playing it; however it is no where near as good as the Gothic series. I would recommend that you play this first and then work your way up the Gothic series, so your games get better as you go.
Other than the lack of different female bases in the game, it's a gorgeous game.

Risen is an often overlooked but stellar RPG.  This is an RPG for grown ups.  If you rip off an npc in a shady deal, they'll glady tell you to go fluff yourself!  The gameplay is challenging and not easy so save often.  Even the mundane enemies pose a threat and combat is very tactical.  Swordplay is not all attacking, you must parry and learn the right moment to strike and use combos.  Magic is also strategic. Mana is limited but mages can be powerful, but still need to time their spells wisely and have a backup plan (staff or swords) or an escape route!  The plot is entertaining and the world is very believeable and realistic.  I would say this game is an acquired taste, but quite a gem in the rough.  I'd say it's better than Dragon Age and slightly below Fallout 3 / New Vegas in terms of fun.  One of the most rewarding things is the difficulty.  It causes you to think when you fight and use strategy (and save games) which most mainstream games are too scared to do.
